content:
Posted: January 18
												The thing that makes Vindictus so dissapointing is that somewhere amid the tedium and endless grind for items in the late game and the boring mindless hack n' slash of the early game areas, there's something that's actually worth playing. It's hard to recommend because anyone playing it will be forced to spend their first ten hours just mashing their mouse buttons - completely mindlessly - while killing through a slew of enemies that have about as much chance of posing a threat as a limbless toddler. Their last ten hours will be spent running the same five bosses over and over again in the hopes that they get drops decent enough to actually play more of the game before they finally quit. But it's the five to ten hours somewhere in the middle there that are worth talking about. The gameplay (when you manage to get to it) is actually great. Much /much/ better than any other action MMO I've ever played (and I've played a lot of them.) It's challenging, fast-paced, and has the highest skill-ceiling of any game of its type, including more single-player oriented games like Dark Souls. It's incredibly fun and rewarding, and completely blows games like Tera, GW2, Blade and Soul, and Dragon's Nest away. Like, its so much better that there's just genuinely no contest. It's the kind of gameplay I can't help but think other games would emulate, if the rest of Vindictus wasn't absolute trash. Getting on a boat and riding somewhere instanced (with multiple semi-long loadscreens in-between) would be bad enough; but add to that the worst difficulty curve of any game I've ever played, and there's an even more serious problem. I've seen more than one review on here talking about the game being a boringly-easy hack n' slash because they quit after five or so hours and never hit the meat of the game. Which is completely understandable considering I did too the first 2 or 3 times I ever played it. Then I'd see youtube videos of someone fighting a giant boss that actually seemed hard, and I'd think, 'wow! That looks awesome! Where the hell was that when I was playing?' Leading to a re-download. See, there are really cool bosses in Vindictus that eventually get extremely hard, but unfortunately they're all hidden behind 10+ hours of dungeons full of trash mobs that the average player could kill their way through while blindfolded. The worst part is, there's very little in-between. It's straight from too-easy trash mobs to 'THIS GUY IS GONNA WRECK YOU!!' It's like playing hours of tutorial level content, only to suddenly hit the final boss who promptly pushes your♥♥♥♥♥♥in. Ultimately though, the thing that really kills the game for me is the end-game. You're cruising along. You managed to slog your way through the boring early stuff and get to real bosses, and suddenly the game is fun. The last five or so hours have been a totally sweet boss-bonanza. You're thinking to yourself, 'wow, thank god I played through all that boring stuff to get here! This game is secretly amazing!' But there's a problem. You've started to notice something. The bosses you fight as you progress are doing more and more damage, and you're doing less and less of it in return. You're becoming a burden to any group you join because you need reviving after one hit, and barely do any damage even when playing perfectly. So the problem becomes clear. Your gear is bad - you need new stuff. Simple fix right? There's just one problem. To continue progressing with the fun parts of the game, you're looking at 20 hours of farming the same bosses over and over again. Minimum. Like, with super luck, you're looking at 20 hours. More likely is something like 60 to 80. To put it simply: this kills the game. I tried. I really did. The fun parts of the game were /so/ fun. They were enough to rekindle the enjoyment I got from playing games - something I haven't really felt since playing Demon's Souls back in 2009. But it wasn't enough. After 10 or so hours of farming, I quit, leaving numerous bosses un-battled and the game un-finished. It's really disappointing, because the festering bloated body of Vindictus hides a skeleton of gameplay that could have been truly great - were the thing placed around it not a disgusting lump of awfulness.

number of helpful: 46 of 53 people (87%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
Product received for free
												It's fun, but in the long run you will be crippled if you're unwilling to spend money The combat system is honestly one of the best I've played for an MMO, even beating out melee oriented action games of the singleplayer variety. The characters have unique playstyles, stylish moves and a great degree of combat is based on player skill. Some of the boss battles are insanely fun, and the fights are engaging so you dont feel like you're just stabbing a giants toe until he keels over. One character can even use his strength to stop certain boss attacks mid-swing and enter a clash of strength if you can time it correctly. It feels pretty badass to save a party member from a potentially fatal blow and in the process hold the boss down for your other teammates to kick his♥♥♥♥♥♥inUnfortunately these attributes are hampered by the fact that end game content is severely walled off. Most of the end game raid partys which are level 80-90 will require a high amount of ATT stat (which is what attack damage is based on), to the point where if you dont upgrade your weapons, its unlikely you will break that ceiling. Although this sounds normal the problem lies hereUpgrading your gear is EXTREMELY RNG dependant. The blacksmith may weaken your items durability and reset all enhancements hes previously done on it back to 0, or just outright destroy it at higher ranks. The magician can enchant your item with special qualities, but once again this is RNG dependant and can damage your gear if it fails. But of course there is a way to prevent these outcomes: $$MONEY$$If you want any realistic chance of upgrading your rare and difficult to obtain weapon to a respectable level, you will NEED either cash shop items or a large amount of resources and attempts. Dont think for a second that other people dont use these items either, pretty much everyone you see will have at least +8 weapons on high level raids. You CAN get these items from events, but they are one use only and quite rare. They aren't guaranteed successes either, they just protect your weapon from getting damaged, so you could stockpile 4 of them from events and level milestones only to reach enhancement level 7. The game would be a 9/10 for me if it wasnt so dependant on RNG to make progress late game. You can try it up to around level 70, before the RNG kicks in too hard, but after that I wouldn't recommend it. But if you like to gamble or have a plenty of cash on hand, go for it.if you think I'm overblowing the whole RNG thing, you can check the wiki for the RNG tables yourself : http://vindictus.gamepedia.com/Item_Enhancement  But keep in mind, the upgrades are not equally spread, so going from +2 to +3 doesnt have anywhere near the same effect as going from +6 to +7TL:DR End game is a slot machine for necessary gear upgrades, and the community is on life support since black desert came out

												RNG.In a simple definition, it's what completely controls our lives.Sure, you may have had your buddy boost you levels 1-90 for free. That's really nice. Maybe you got in some of those double xp weekends too and you got your level easily. That's great, levels are great.But it comes at a price.All gear comes at a price. You may think I mean crafting, but no. Crafting is the easy part.The real price of playing this game is your entire life. The amount of time it takes you to pray to RNG GOD for him to bless you with enough drops to afford your best 90 gear is the same amount of time it takes the average human born, to die.You will die playing this game. This game will ♥♥♥♥ you until you are sucked dry of your emotions and you become an endless farming machine, you will become a slave to NEXON and their NX prices, praying to get money to buy enchanting runes so you don't break your gear while crafting. You will spend the same amount of time getting to max level, adding +1000 dmg to your weapon by enhancing it. Did I mention, if your RNG fails you have to start all over? You do.I ♥♥♥♥ing hate this game but it keeps calling me back for more. I lay in bed and I can't sleep. My daily raids that I can run twice a day call out to me, begging me to run them, begging me to crawl endless dungeons in hope for shining gold, an enchant scroll, a piece of loot that I can finally feel good about the many years it will take to buy that endgame gear. I've sacrificed my friends and drank various blood potions to be blessed with good luck, nothing has worked. I've begged ferghus to "Welcome me to the forge" dozens of times. All I can do with the rest of my life is pray to God I will make some ♥♥♥♥ing money. The combat is pretty fun, though. Would reccomend, 10/10.

												I've played this game since CBT and it's been awesome. It is a very fast paced action oriented MMO. To be honest, I didn't pay much attention to the story as I played it like Monster Hunter. I enjoyed this game even without the story. The beginning can be very dull but it gets better later on. Having friends and guild members to mess around with in instances and raids definitely makes a difference. There won't be much players on lower level instances for the most part unless there's going to be a new character released. Expect to grind for materials for armor unless you have the cash to buy it. Disclaimer: I haven't played the game too much after season 2 arrivedPros:- Unique and fun Characters- Character skills are awesome- Each Character has a choice between two weapon types- Amazing visuals- Combat is fluid and fast- Very challenging (soloing instances, raids etc)- There's a storyline- Perverted camera at the end of each instance- No more token system- Spin to win (go play spear Lann, though you probably will get kicked from raids)Cons:- Gender locked (for those who have problems with this)- Lag/DC out of an instance (I remember the servers lagged pretty hard and everyone was trying to crash it because it wasn't getting restarted)- Grind fest- Pay to win (can buy revives and instant potions to your advantage)- Enhancing/Enchanting weapons may require you to spend real cash (not required though as it just increase the chances of success)- You have to go through the cut scene on the boat every time :/- Can't hide megaphone chatIf none of the cons bother you, check it out its an amazing game.

												Another peg in the belt of "Why would anyone play a nexon game?"Game seemed fun gameplay-wise, but for some reason they decided to remove all gold value from items and missions for the first XX levels of the game, so as a new player you can't buy any gear, craft, buy potions, basically do anything. I guess they did it to fight gold farming bots, which doesn't seem to have done anything because I still saw gold spammers. All it did was make the bots change their farming strategy and make the new player experience awful.TL;DR: Nexon doesn't care about their customers. Nexon doesn't care about making good games. Nexon cares about making money. Do not play Nexon games.

												The game was pretty awesome during the first several years since (open/closed) beta. However, now the game is obviously suffering from many afflictions that a MMO goes through going past it's prime. Events are no longer entertaining or worth doing, events have been degraded to the point where it's either free consumables from cash shop, increased EXP/AP/Raid Counts etc, or cash shop sales. Typical blatant cash grabs by Nexon in the form of in-game pets or vanity sets, seriously $30 for vanity set? Being able to run the later raids especially in Season 2 requires excellent gear, most of which will be forever out of a large majority of player's reach, unless you buy gold... The inflation in this game is pretty bad but maybe not as ridiculous as other MMOs but new player's have almost no chance. Population decline.The actual gameplay revolving around 3rd person camera is actually quite good, it is very reminiscent and similar to how Ninja Gaiden operates. Overall a MMO that had great potential but is marred by Nexon's incompetence and/or greed in addition to the inevitable degenerative effects of human nature...

content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												First off, this game is great with friends. Level 1-50 is easy.  At level 50, you unlock "Hero" mode which makes the game harder and much more fun (if you have the gear). This game has its flaws but I don't know a game that doesn't. If you want to give this game a fair shot level to 50 and play a couple of the battles on "Hero" and join some raids. This will give you a pretty good idea of what to expect for end-game content.I recommend finding a good guild through the Vindictus website or in-game using the "Search Guild" function. You can also see if any guild is advertising with the !megaphone (purple font) as well.One of the biggest strengths of this game is the story. At first, it begins kind of slow but it really picks up towards the end. If anything, get through all of that and if you STILL don't like the game then quit. It's relatively easy to solo all the missions because of different settings. Or better yet, grab a few friends or find people in-game to complete the story together.The flaws or drawbacks is random lag spikes/fps drops, not a very vocal community (there are some bots wandering around), and high level end game content requires a lot of rare gear to participate in. Money shop is a little on the expensive side but it doesn't necessarily unbalance the game to my knowledge.Love it or hate it. Just give it a try.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												Now, before you end up complaining about my hours and the negative review, let me just start this off with, I actually really loved and actually still do enjoy playing this game.        But, there is this little thing I like to call caring about your consumers. The Player appreciation event would've been better off being called the "player depreciation event". The contents they gave out during that event were not very good and not really even worth it really, plus this event happened right after an event that went completely downhill in the last few days. Several of my friends stopped playing after that even because of how big of a♥♥♥♥♥♥off it was.       Now let me tell you of this event. It was a bingo event, aka for this game, kill specific monsters on certain days, collect a number, and bingo at the end. I'm ok with  level cap for events but don't you dare put it on the last 3 days to make all the lower level people who really wanted the event rewards to be completely crushed. Because, I don't know if you know or not, but not EVERYONE pays in a free to play game, hence the "F2P".     Now that is not even the worst part. On the forums, you can clearly see multiple people complaining about the level cap randomly popping out of nowhere, and you can also see people who got the numbers that was currently impossible to obtain by their level be complaining to support in time. But you know what? They nitpicked and only gave it to the people who cried about it. Because you know what? After a ton of people complain about the level cap and not getting the numbers, lets not give everyone below x number the numbers. Because you know someone who isn't doing the event isn't gonna benefit from the numbers while people who were crushed can actually get what they deserve.      Now if you like hack and slashes then by all means play the game. I like it, and would like to play more. But the fact that they literally don't care about their consumers really. Their servers are pretty trash as well. So I would love to play more, but I just can no bring myself to play anything unless they figure a good way out to repay for the trashy excuses they have pulled out of their ***** and their garbage player "appreciation" event/events in general. They only care towards their paying players, everyone else can pretty much just♥♥♥♥♥♥off in their eyes.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												-This is from a non-subscriber point of view-      I can agree with what most other are saying about the title. Overall, It's very fun and engaging. It allows you to have a sense of acomplishment and excitement about your character throughout the initial stages of the game. The content is very interesting if you read the dialogue, and I believe it can appleal to fast pace action fans and rpg fans alike. However, in my opinion, from lvl 30 and on is where you begin to realise your character is starting to buckle.     I myself, as a non paying player, followed several online guides related to my class in order to obtain the "optimal" skill levels and gear necessary for comfortable to advanced gameplay. Getting as close to these recommendations as possible, I continued to progress my character. After breezing through the first couple of chapters being able to solo all of the content on "hard" difficulty, I found it more and more necessary to have others in your party to be able to make any progress through higher tiers of content. This is completely understandable for "Raid" and other missions requiring exceptional damage output. However, the fact that I am not able to gear my character appropriately with that stats on the gear that I can OPENLY obtain, makes it extremely difficult to be of any significant value to other players who have donated personal funds to advance their character as such. Therefore, I feel it's going to take more than an average "casually serious" player, to be able to have any inforcing role in true end-game content. My positive recommendation would be for any player not wanting to progress seriously, or any willing to pay for a more serious, exciting end game experience. Simple as that. It's true, there are elitist jerks in the community who want to demoralize you and make you feel like less of a person through a video game. This can be said with any MMO ever released, but it's your game that this company released for free for YOU. You should be able to play it the way YOU want to. However, unless you are able to pay a premium, you will never live up to the expectation of your fellow gamer. It's very sad that a gaming community has come to this, but what can we do as players?     That being said, I will continue to play the game FOR FREE and document my experiences and how I am able to proess as a casual, non-paying player. Cheers!

number of helpful: 42 of 56 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												3000h+ edit \o/Very well-done Korean Hack n Slash MMO-RPG Co-op game. I've been playing since Closed Beta, there are ups and down such as usual lags that most of Free-to-Play games tend to have, games combat area is hosted by a player rather then Vindictus server, so connection between you and the host tend to be very important. Just to note, when they have outfits on sale for limited time only, they mean it, those things never comes back on sale except on very rare cases. (real money outfits. If its rune of some sort, high chance it will be back later on but not often.)To answer if this game is Pay To Win, I would rather say this game is more of Luck to Win. There are so many RGN (Random Generated Number?) things are there, such as 95% of raid drops, which you kinda want a good drop for money if you do not want to farm (personally I dont think Vindictus is a farming game, its a bit hard to 'farm' and time consuming compare to other mmo) However this doesnt really happen often that sometime you wont even really get anything thats worth a money untill couple month later of running every daily raids.Above RNG drop rate is to change with new sealshop update so anyone who bother to farm raids for a month can have full geared 80 set.  Enhancing (Success rate 100% -> 75% -> etc etc decrease down to 40%)Enchanting (Depends on Ranks, and your input. Almost everything thats useful enchants have 40~50% rate of success and it can blow off your equipments when not used with rune)I would say Enchancing and Enchanting is the number one reason why people come to quit this game.Infusion (Either gives you crappy♥♥♥♥♥stat or even negative stat) Ofcourse, all of above doesnt matter (enhancing/enchanting/Infusion) as much if you are not one of those 'elite' people. (..I kinda am)Characters have their own name(other then the one that you name. People call out the characters given name to defind their 'Class'), and are gender locked. I didnt really mind about Gender-locked system since I was never really bothered by 'I really wish I could play as a female/male character' All 8 Character have their personal weapons that does have very different characteristic and I suggest you try other 'class' if you do not like the one you've chosen.So far in order of release - Lann(M) - Dual Sword (Shares with Vella)/Dual Spear Fiona(F) - Hammer/Sword + Small Shield/Large Shield (Large shield is practically useless)Evie(F) - Staff / Scythe Karok(M) - Pillar/Blaster Kai(M) - Bow/Crossgun  Vella(F) - Dual Sword (Weapon is Shared with Lann)/Dual Chain Hurk(M) - Great Sword Lynn(F) - Battle GlaiveCombat system is very well done I always comes back to Vindictus due to its unique combat system thats rarely found in any other MMO RPG. Very awesome effects but carries counter side. Sometimes raid becomes messive 'Wherethefkistheboss' situation when the boss happened to be a human character size. There is an option to not show other players effect but human size monsters are still not visible when its inbetween 5,6 characters.)Because you have to time and counter/block enemy attack when required, its hard to do so with bad connection. Since servers are not provided except in 24men raids, connection between you and the host tend to be reallllllllly important. You will NOT be able to move when its a crucial movement, and attack if you are running with someone thats not able to host or in long distant area from you. Story, you will love the story compare to other mmos if you are interested in reading them. There are two story, Season One, and Season Two. Its easily explained like a quest in any MMO, where main character is asked to take A or B route. So those who take Season 1 would be considered as they have taken A route when those who take on Season 2 would be considered as they have taken B route. Which one is better? Personally I will say Season One. I just couldnt come to like of Season Two. Season One however is very very well done in my opinion, I suggest everyone to read them.There will be couple areas player come to be bored for the new players and quits mostly in that area which is around level 25 ~ 35 esh. However real game starts over level 60+, I suggest anyone that plays to take time and play up to 60 where they can start the raids. You like dress-up games? because Vindictus do a good job of it. Yea sure they do have couple outfits you have to buy in real money to enjoy your new look, but there are only maybe 3-4 outfits thats not limited time only and all of them arnt really customizable compare to the ones that you can get from in-game. They do have stats attached to them however they arnt so game changing, limited outfits does have higher stats, but personally I dont see much difference, it helps for lower ATT users to join higher req dungeons which is set by another player. (Limited time only outfits have 500+ ATT/MATT increase) Games town really have nothing to see if you are into looking for every single details. the very first town we incounter is the most populated place and people tend to hang around there, making new friends, untill they find a guild that is active and have their 'own' channel. Community is.. bad..? Im not sure honostly, since I've found my 'buddies' shortly after started playing this game. I did play around in Vindictus offcial community forum as Seanna, translating Kr stuff. But I got busy and stopped translating things. When sometime I visit the forum, it kinda shows that they arnt taking care of their forum that much. As long as you find group that you like, you probably wont really care about the rest of community.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												This game breaks my heart. It has the best fighting system in any free to play game i have ever seen. It is faster, more simple, more intuitive, and requires much more skill on the player's part.There are very few hot-bar skills. For the most part, you control every step, hit, and dodge. And there is an impact every time you hit something combined with realistic blood splotches, very rewarding. Also, there is a fighting style for anyone.but... To unlock the full potential of your character, you have to grind to 52 just to use all your skills. From there, you probably need to reach level cap and grind for many days more to rank these skills up to the point where you can fight effectively (i.e. Battle Respiration and Stamina Mastery. If you are a melee character and you dont have these maxed, you will have some trouble keeping up with certain bosses). But even when you have maxed all of your skills and can use your character effectively, you will be hard-pressed to get into a raid party simply because you might not have the stats necessary. So how do you get stats? You get it with very expensive and rare gear. This gear is simply unobtainable to casual players who dont want to spend money. Nexon wants their money...The game does have a saving grace, however, and this is why I love it. There are some great guilds out there that are willing to help out new players with leveling, gearing, money earning, and enjoying the game. Many powerful guilds will be willing to take under-geard folks into end-game raids for chances at loot and practice. Any active guild will, to some degree, fulfill most of Nexon's shortcomings and make the game fun (I say "most" because there are problems that NOBODY can fix like server issues).If you are interested in playing, find a guild and be active in it. They will treat you well and you will have a good time.(Good Guilds: Colossus/Wanton, Citadel, E S P A D A, Sweg, Peace, StormWingsv3, VforVindictus, and many more that you will discover with experience +wink)

number of helpful: 23 of 26 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3
												I actually would really like to give this game a thumbs up. I have a couple hundred hours in the game (probably an extra 400) before they reached out to Steam. The combat is unlike anything I've ever experienced in another game. The reason why I give this a thumbs down is the enhancement/enchantment methods that are practically required in order to access the "end game" content... but for starters, I'll talk about what is good about the game.TL;DR. The game is designed for you to use the cash shop in order to progress without relying on luck. However, the cash shop is so bad, it keeps away players, but since this is a free to play game, it's also the only thing keeping it alive.Well, the only 3 good things about the game...1: The combat is just.. how do I explain... the hitboxes are clean, the invulnerability dodge ticks are cleaner, character movement and enemy movement is spectacular. It's a hack and slash game that is really good at hacking and slashing with an attempt to tie in RPG elements before and after battles. I don't care much for story in games, but for this story it's interesting. The combat is the only reason why I sometimes think about coming back to this game.2: Copious amounts of customization. Hundreds of hairstyles, tattoo styles, facial customization, armor and weapon transmogrification, etc.3: Every couple of months they have an event that gives you free stuff from their shop.Now for the negatives.1: Player base. There are more people on World of Warcraft private servers than on this game for Christ's sake. I think the peak (last time I played it which was spring of 2016 was like 700 players online, and a few of them were gold-farming bots) A majority of content after around lvl 50, you'll need friends or randoms to help get through dungeons/quests. You'll  be lucky to find any, as most people are veterans and are just constantly doing end-game content.2: Store prices are insane. The few people who do buy a crapload of stuff from the store are the people basically keeping this game afloat. I'm talking about 5 bucks for a single piece of armor transmog. There is Helmet, Chest, Legs, Gloves, Boots... so we're talking 20 dollars for a full-body customization that only applies to one character. Armor and weapon enhancement/enchantment varies if you fail or not. (I'll get to that later). Character re-customization is also extremely expensive. Like I said before, the character customization is a plus for this game, but you only have access to around 10 hairstyles. The other 40+ must be bought. Same with tattoos, and underwear. I'm talking like 20 bucks just to change a hairstyle.. nothing to laugh about.3: The armor and weapon enhancement. The system goes as follows:Armor and Weapons can be ENHANCED from +0 to +15 (0 being worst, 15 being best)Armor and Weapons can be ENCHANTED using scrolls from rank F, E, D, C, B, A, 9, 8, 7. (F being worst, 7 being best)For Enhancement = first 3 levels are guaranteed. Levels 4-5, you can fail, the rank goes down by 1 and item durability decreases permanently. Levels 6-8, you can fail and the rank goes back down to 0 and item durability decreases permanently. Levels 9-15, you can fail and the item is destroyed. You can get it back, after spending a fortune. ONCE. Fail again, and you lose the item permanently.For Enchantment = rank F-A, you can fail and the scroll is destroyed, but the item loses durability. Rank 9-7, both the scroll and item are destroyed. You can get the item back (not the scroll), but again, you must pay a fortune.. ONCE.Fail again, you lose it permanently.The risk and reward for doing this is so out of balance, it's not worth playing the game. The risk being, you've just destroyed your item that you've farmed for weeks, maybe months... the reward being.. you gain minor stats.Here's where they get you though. They have these "enhancement runes" and "enchantment runes" that you can purchase to protect your item from being destroyed. If you fail, the rune is destroyed instead. You can see now how this can be quite costly. I've put 30 bucks in this game just to see all 5 of my runes get destroyed, and then my item destroyed afterwards.Now imagine being me, except do that about 6 more times. (I learned my lesson about spending money the second time I tried enhancing items... everything afterwards was free stuff from events that the game held and gave out free stuff, but I had to wait months and months just to acquire all the necessary materials) It's completely random as to who gets what they want. We have me, who has destroyed item after item trying to get the necessary stats to access end-game content... then we have a friend of mine who gets a +15 weapon on his second try. There's no skill involved. Just luck. Too much luck. That's why I can't stand this game. I love it but I hate it more than I love it. This is the main reason I decide not to get back into the game.4: Professions are just wierd. There's an NPC that can craft everything for you, the only difference between learning a profession and crafting something using the NPC is that using the profession uses less materials, and takes way longer to craft. Problem is, you will always out-progress your profession, so you are way too far ahead of your profession, causing you to either backtrack to farm materials or get rich and just buy your way through. The main problem I have with professions though, is that the higher your skill, the longer it takes to craft. At the later stages of training professions, you'll be crafting something for a solid half hour. I'm not even joking.. like literally 32 minutes of standing there waiting for you to craft some high level gloves. You'll literally have to alt+tab and like watch a couple youtube videos, meanwhile, the NPC can make it instantly.5: "Battle Supplies Surprise." It's an option in the cash shop to purchase a box that can give you random gear. The chance is pretty low to obtain the gear, but when you do get it, you can sell it to players for quite a bit of money. Back when this first came out, the max level in the game was level 80. The box released level 80 gear. People would buy these boxes and just rely on luck to get their level 80 items instead of farm for them. So at that point in time it was pay to win... but when they increased the max level to 90, it's not so bad. (I view it as a negative because it once represented a pay to win aspect, which imbalanced the game's marketplace)6: The discrepancy between armor tiers. From character level 1-60, you have armor sets every 4-6 levels. You're improving at a steady rate, it's nice and flows easy. After level 60, you get nothing until 70. After 70, nothing until 80. After 80, nothing until 90. What's worse is, a +10 level 60 item is just as good as a +0 level 70 item. A +10 level 70 item is as good as a +0 level 80 item. A +10 level 80 item is just as good as a +0 level 90 item. So there's no real reason to even enhance or enchant a weapon/armor piece until you reach level 90. The problem is, if you don't enhance, you'll fall behind in the quests that require level 70 and higher. You're going to have to enhance weapons at the least in order to progress steadily, or get carried by someone that's a higher level than you... so you better prepare to either lose your weapon or purchase enhancement runes from the ever so lovely cash shop.7: Optimization. If you have a potato, don't download this game. It really dumps on your CPU. Hard.8: Nexon. Horrible customer service (probably because they have only like 10 people working on the entire game) known for their cash-grab schemes.9: Pathetic excuse of a PvP system. It's buggy, laggy, and extremely imbalanced. There are only 3 classes (out of 9) that can win a fight. (For those that want to know, it's Evie, Karok and Hurk, and maybe a Lann, but only if you play like a god 100% of the time) It is perfectly clear that they only care about PvE.

content:
Posted: March 22
												This is a game on the edge of greatness.The combat is unique and frankly unprecendented in the way it works for an MMO. So many MMO's claim they have good combat but it's just some version of the tired "cooldown combat" that WoW pioneered and everyone else either ran into the ground or at best made slightly more tolerable. This game has cooldowns I suppose but it's not just numbers and flashy effects. I played mostly as the sorceress and every spell was great. Supreme amounts of weight were behind every attack and the variety in spells was great. The other classes are almost as satisfying.But this is a Nexon game. The combat is good but other non-MMOs have better combat. And what Vindictus has can't carry the game through endless hours of grinding. I've had friends much better at tolerating it, and for some it is enough. With the right mentality it's possible to put 100's of hours into this game and enjoy it. I had fun too but the chasm was too deep for me.If you like Korean MMOs already and can tolerate all their usual garbage (grind or pay, limited time cash shop items, etc.) then you'll probably love this game. If you don't have that tolerance, run.

number of helpful: 22 of 25 people (88%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												I have thousands of hours clocked into this game, way more than the amount I have on steam. This game is definately deserving of more players, but it's understandable why a lot of people quit, so I'll put down the common pros and cons.PROS-Honestly the best combat system for hack and slash on any free to play MMORPG I've ever seen.-Common events for players to help improve their gameplay and stats.-10+ different types of characters to play-A new character is released almost every year-The game gives you a training option to help improve your skill-Some events include expensive cash shop items that make it easier to get higher teir gear, but this is REALLY expensive.CONS-Dungeons of 4-8 players are run by hosts and not the servers-Royal raids of 16+ tend to be pretty laggy-Improving your stats can prove to be very annoying at the higher levels and really expensive.-Raids get very difficult around the level 80 mark, but never impossible-Characters are Gender lockedIt's easy to understand why a lot of people don't play Vindictus, or give up at higher levels; just remember that their are a lot of characters, you will eventually find the one for you.Cash Shop:The cash shop is very fair to people that don't use it. It's mainly cosmetic items and any items that help improve your stats don't reduce the in-game money cost to improve them, aside from the possible destruction of gear. There are some events that help remove the possibility of both gear and money loss, but these cash shop items are brutally expensive. There are common events as well that allow you to get cosmetic items without the need for using the cash shop, along with many other items in the cash shop.Difficulty:Starting off you will find that Vindictus is somewhat easy, but the more you progress the more you'll realise just how high of a difficulty the game can be. You will probably find bosses you think are impossible, but this can only be due to you using the wrong character, or not having the patience to learn the boss itself. I assure you that any boss can be fought with full confidence regardless of difficulty, it just takes time.Honestly worth playing, especially with the new type of events they started releasing that basically give you high grade gear for your level to help you start off and get used to the game.

												I've been playing this game for a few years at this point, and am motivated to leave this review in the wake of something that has happened in the community recently (which is why I installed the 'Steam version' to review it - because if you post anything 'negative' on channels they control they'll just delete it and ban you), though I will do my best to remain objective:Pros:*Great combat system.*Enough character/weapon types that you will probably find something you like.Cons:*Upgrading your gear usually destroys said gear (without using 'paid items').*The amount of RNG is nauseating.*'Paid' items are very expensive.*The security program the game uses (BlackCipher) is incredibly invasive in terms of what it scans and probably uses more CPU power than the actual games does. *The real 'con' of the game is that the Nexon NA staff seem to treat players/the community like 'annoyances' rather than an important part of the game. This once again was made clear very recently when a well known/helpful player that had already been falsely banned once (a improper ban that was overturned) was improperly banned again to which Nexon NA basically said, 'We've already fixed a mistake we made once, so we won't do it again.' What?? So if Nexon makes a mistake once it's 'hey we'll fix it", but if they make a mistake twice it's, "go pound sand'? Great system/people...That is the type of management this game has, beware.So it's worth giving a try, but not worth spending any money on.

												You could probably more than double my hours if you count the nexon launcher. Without leaving a super long review:The combat is great; 2017 and I still come back and play this game. Enough variety in characters and their respective mechanics. Newest raid is challenging and very rewarding to do, I wish all the content was this enjoyable, however...Progressing in this game is not easy. I would say to give this game a chance, but unless you have ALOT of time to farm gold, start off an old account or dump somekind of money in, prepare for a grind if you want endgame. Just try not to burn yourself out (unless you're a masochist). In the end just upgrade at your own pace and make the game enjoyable for yourself.

content:
Posted: March 1
												I have played this game for 3 years, so do not pay attention to the time counter on Steam, because this was just available after the EU service migration.Vindictus has certainly one of the unique PvE combat system of all action MMORPG. Every actions such as attacks, dodge and interaction are responding the way they should do. You can not play this type of combat passively, on the contrary, you must pay attention for every actions you make. Thus this game requires your skill a lot, which is so much fun to play.Overall the semi-realism character design and level design are beautiful, which show off in the latish updates. The equipments look interesting which give you a variety of combination between various type of armor e.g. cloth, light, heavy, plate and importantly avatar sets, which is only available through NX shop or special events.Now that was the first glance of a shiny game. Of course there is a downside, a major downside to be more exact. But let me gather them bit by bit.First of all, since the Europe version (XE) is wiped, you are going to play Vindictus on North America Premiere version. This Premiere version is not equivalent to the original Korean version, for some reason. This can be see in the play mechanic of Vella where you can hold shift to go into Cross Stance and release the button to cancel the animation. Okay, this point is only understandable to Vindictus player.But it is rather disappointing to not get the full potential of the game.To be honest, this game is not PvP friendly at the beginning. Maybe there was an unbalanced time for people who enjoy PvP content, but do not get the idea of playing this game for PvP. It is not worth it and boring to be clear.The other thing is the Peer-to-Peer connection to get into raids or battle. This type of connection requires you a decent upload rate to setting up raids or battles. Consequently if you have bad internet connection then you are limited to enjoy the exciting content of the game: raids. Raid is boss battle only which require you, depends on difficulty, a lot of focus and skill. As follows, you will experience lags, stuttering and unresponsive. So it depends on your hoster, because he/she should also have a good connection to carry the party member. The downside is, if you are not fulfil the requirement of the hoster, such as low ATK or ABC (Attack Speed, Balance, Critical Hit) then he is able to kick you out of the board. And this is a disappointing feeling for player to be „left“ out.Furthermore the loading time is a thing. A feature which is still common in modern game, but the loading time in this game is literally too long! You are waiting roughly 30 seconds to board the actual battle and once you have completed it, take another 30 seconds on top of that? No, how about a random time from 1 minute to never ending battles? Not funny at all.Rather than that, searching for specific items on the marketplace can give you a random disconnection due to its loading time. Not only that, you also get disconnection in any time. No matter if you are raiding, selling, sitting, chatting or waiting for battle result. Once you get a disconnection, you are out – restart the whole game to come back.Also you get a 10 minutes IP-lock every time your IP has changed. As a result you are not able to sell or buy items, open boxes, claiming mails, which is annoying in a long term. 10 more minutes will not hinder „hacker“ to delete your precious treasure. You should know how to secure your account.Finally the major issue on this game is performance. Game performance is THE most essential thing for a good game. Vindictus is not optimized at all. You will never see the 60 fps marker in any raids or battles for a good gaming experience. No matter if you fulfil the system requirement, which is nuts, or you have access the high horse power gaming rig, you never get the 60 fps – okay except for log-in screen or facing walls. To be truth, your fps will be in the low 30 or 20 in raids/battles and crowded city, it is just the fact.This review contains game experiences so far without going in details to the publisher side Nexon Inc. Of course there are a few issues going on such as blocked country, bots and gold sellers, TirCoins, banned player, cash grab events, where you literally have to buy NX (real money) to get excellent stuff.Nexon is responsible for this game and it will surely affects your game experience as a result. So keep that in mind.This game has reached his age and it is not worth to begin with.So in a nutshell, do yourself a favour and use your limited time in something else. This game is not worth to play.tl;dr++ unique combat system (PvE base)++ competitive boss fight+ beautiful character design, level design- different game version NA Premiere ≠ KR Premiere- PvP... come on are you kidding me?-- Peer-to-Peer connection for raids and battles-- long loading time (boarding boat, searching marketplace, ending battles)-- disconnection appears randomly (another RNG feature?)-- 10 minutes IP lock--- performance is ridiculously trash

number of helpful: 29 of 39 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12
												One of the best Action Combat MMOs I have ever played.PROS: Good free to play game you can easily enjoy without paying money. Outstanding fast-paced combat with lots of variety, and decent graphics (back then, anyway). My friends and I played the HELL out of this game a few years ago.  What really kept us playing was the great action-based combat, and amazing amount of detail and intricacy involed with the production this game.  When we discovered this game and how great it was, we started the guild called "V for Vindictus" and it quickly became one of the largest guilds in the game.  Vindictus is really one of the best free to play action-based combat MMOs we have ever played.CONS: The game is a few years old now, and showing its age.  Also, my account got hacked a long time ago, so I pretty much stopped playing since then.  It is almost entirely instance-based dungeons, where you que up solo or in a group depending on the level of the dungeon, etc. you need to do.  The problem with groups is sometimes you get people from the other side of the world connecting to the game using potato-powered internet, which will then lag out the game for everyone.  My advice is to avoid pickup groups, and join a guild to group with.MORE CONS: Whats with Nexon allowing trigger-happy, power hungry forum admins that ban some of the most infuential people for Vindictus of ALL TIME? (Fan-site and gaming community leaders)? A game company that cares little to none for its customers, which is the cheap way for Nexon. That forum admin should at least be permanently banned. It seems like many recent players are saying the game is dying, which is not surprising, as it has had a pretty good run for a Nexon game.LOLWUT:  If you really like action-based combat games with depth, then I recommend you just give Vindictus a try.  Other than that, I recommend most people avoid it, or if you DO play it, don't spend any money, since Nexon has pretty much screwed over the player-base of this game.

 A very long review incoming, you have been warned... (no TL;DR, no potato either). Been playing for at least 3 years now (have more hours outside Steam, about 8,000+) and this is what I have to say about the game:Pros: -Great Combat System         -Can get basically everything for free in-game (mostly pay for cosmetics and the like)         -Can still be able to look good without paying for cosmetics (no seriously, don't be tempted to buy Nx, u get rewarded with cosmetic coupons upon reaching certain levels and from some events)         -Awesome looking armor sets at higher levels         -Able to solo almost everything         -Uses the party's host connection for boats/raids (Uses game server for the 24-man raids)          -Boob Physics, like, lots of boob physics         -Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ I can see your panti- *gets slapped* -Oh, and Iset + Succubus Queen (10/10 would stay to watch the cutscenes) Cons: -Cash Shop a tad bit overpriced          -Publisher is Nexon :/          -Free option at character customization screen is meh (it has a boob slider tho :D)          -Can get boring/repetitive (might wanna bring some friends)          -Party has a bad host (host connection is low/too laggy)? You'll have a bad time          -Heavily Instanced          -Attempting to +15 your equipment (or enchant them) can be... quite tedious          -A lot of grinding at higher levels          -RNGesus please (RNG is really low lol)          -Damn you Ferghus!!!!          -Screw you too Brynn :c           -Nexon wtf, fix your sht (no really Nexon, we need better servers and for you to optimize your game more)           -Game/Server Crashes Great game, would recommend to those intrigued to try it out and see how you like it, you might enjoy it like me, if you can get past the heavy instancing, immense grinding/farming for materials, and Nexon itself :PAnd if you're looking for a rating, guess I'll give it a 8/10 (10/10 for the boobs and would blow up their weapon again)Update #1: I've been looking at other reviews for Vindi and seeing lots of ppl with problems. If you're having start-up problems: don't run using steam, instead download the nexon launcher and run from there (copy the files instead of redownloading)Update #2: For those saying stuff like "camera changes when attacking", that shouldn't happen. You're supposed to have total control over your camera; don't just attack and allow your FoV to change.Update #3: Friends/Social list is bugged, so currently only way to add someone in-game is to right-click on their character or name in chat.Helpful tip #1: Able to launch on Steam but having problems connecting to the server or something? Use -tcp in the launch option.Helpful tip #2: I'd recommend using the Nexon launcher to run this game rather than from Steam, trust me on this. (The Steam launcher is buggy and wont launch the game for some people)Friendly tip #1: The game isn't yet optimized for Windows 10, details have been posted on the game's official site.Need any questions to be answered? Feel free to pm me, though I might not be able to answer some questions as I've only have been playing since Arisha's release (a few years ago) and not from the beta like most veterans.

number of helpful: 15 of 15 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												-Before I say anything, I highly recommmend installing the Nexon launcher to play ANY Nexon game rather than through Steam. I notice many people unfairly batting Vindictus as well as other Nexon games on Steam like Maplestory simply because they cannot launch and play them due to authentication problems.-While the MMO action rpg genre has seen more competition in the past years, with games like TERA, BnS, and the upcoming Black Desert, Vindictus was a show stopper at its time of release, and still holds up just fine today. From its stunning graphics, easy-to-learn/hard-to-master gameplay, wide cast of characters, dedicated (though small) community, customizable hud, and soundtrack.Unlike other games from this genre, Vindictus does not burden your keyboard and screen with endless amounts of skills, items and abilities. While there is still a hotbar for items and some skills, the combat in this game is highly combo-based, using both left and right mouse clicks to utilize light and heavy attacks. Even magic-based characters, such as Evie, Arisha, or Sylas, are not held down from the traditional mage gameplay of smashing your face on your keyboard to spam abilities, and use this system. Despite the simplified combat, each character boasts unique mechanics, abilities, and personality (some more than others) that mingle with the usual combat system to magically create a different experience for each character. It may be simple, but it certainly isn't easy. Along with hacking and slashing your foes, you will be required to dodge/block and constantly dance around bosses to avoid attacks, because if you don't, it's gonna hurt. ALOT.Vindictus, as its name hints, is pretty brutal. Just like in real life, enemies die in 1-3 hits. However, that also means you can die just as easily. Though not apparent early on, the difficulty of this game spikes HEAVILY, if you're not prepared. Vindictus's later bosses bring great urgency to your character, because soon as you start to slip, you can find yourself fighting for your life after taking 1-3 hits. Later bosses also bring unique mechanics to further keep you on your toes. Things do become easier with better gear, which is now relatively easy to attain yourself given the time and effort. Even though many people complain that this game is p2w, I wouldn't go as far to say that, despite there being microtransactions. Sure, the highest levels of enhants and enhancements require you to pay up some cash for risk blowing up your gear, but if you're lucky enough to strike gold with a rare drop or enough farming, you can earn enough gold to buy gear from someone else who's done the work of making gear for you! ^^ Personally, I only ever spent money for cosmetics and means to advertise merch to the server, but this can easily be done through the official forums, which is surprisingly active in the trading department.I'm mixed about Vindictus's story. As some may know, this game is technically a prequel of Mabinogi. For the first arc, humans and fomors are at war and humans want to kill all fomors in order to reach paradise, 'Erinn', which is the world in which Mabinogi takes place. Simple, but the story expands much farther in that, which I do not want to spoil for others. Currently, there are 3 arcs. Each main arc is a 'season', and although each have different themes, they all have a loose connection. Alone, the individual stories seem to get lost in themselves, and most definitely requires a summary to fully grasp. What interests me is that each season adds another piece to the puzzle of Vindictus's grand picture, so I'll be sure to stick around for the truest end of the game. There aren't many interesting or beloved characters in the story, but they're passable. They're like stuffed animals. They don't really have a whole much to do with, but you come to like their company as you play the game.As said before, Vindictus is brutal. Enemies, bosses, and your character all REALLY want to kill eachother, and it damn well does a good job at presenting that. Not over the top, not too friendly. It's just right.As a player who started during the advent of season 2, I say give it a try. If you can't run other MMOs and are intimidated by the screenshots, you'd be surpised that you might be able to play this one (at low settings) since this game runs on Source. The community may be small, but it is growing, and with the EU and NA server merge, the game will certainly feel more alive at the early-mid levels. Even once you're at the latest content, there's a constant flow of updates with even more content to chew on.Not to mention boob physics.

												You could fill an olympic pool with all the mmos, free to play and otherwise, that have died since VinD came out in North America. VinD is still kicking, and there's two good reasons for that: 1) it's a great game, and 2) it has a great business model.As far as skill based action mmos, no other game is even close to over the VinD experience. This game looks better in DX9 than half the junk coming out in 2016. It plays better than anything in the genre.If you hate the cash shop in this game then you've never seen a bad cash shop. Frankly it's as benign as imaginable. If you never want to spend a dime, you sure can. But you probably should, and it will improve your experience, even if it doesn't make you stronger.Some Cons:There's no real PvP in this game (nobody plays it anyways), just competing against others to do more damage. If you have a bad connection, you're going to have a bad time. This game does not love potato PCs, or lag. The servers are held together by paperclips and glue.

												The only MMO experience that I've actually enjoyed. (Dev's note: Look to this game for ideas for your MMO. Vindictus actually has characters and narrative with a little substance rather than a sequence of generic fedex quests. The UI is also brilliant. Game mechanics that actually get you into the fight rather than spamming macro keys.  That being said Vindictus does fall flat in a few areas. It would be far more immersive if NPC dialogue was voice acted. More/better ambient sounds wouldn't go astray either. My biggest gripe though is that the F2P micro-transactions really aren't that micro... $30 for increased inventory space? Really?  That's more than I purchase most Steam titles for.  I would be more likely to make purchases if it seemed like better value but you could easily spend a tonne of money in this game for really minor customizations. Over all though I highly recommend this to anyone new to MMOs, or to anyone who finds traditional MMOs too generic and hollow.

												For the positives of the game:-Fun to play if you like hack and slash.-Great graphics.-Somewhat decent storyline.For the negatives of the game:-Nexon game, so expect F2P = P2W-Really unstable server, game goes down a lot when you don't need it to.-You really need to bring friends into this game to make it enjoyable. Without friends, you're going to be going in empty for pretty much many of your dungeon runs.-Mediocre customer service/PR-Events are more of people sitting around doing nothing for ~2 hours.-Events ingame are more often just as unstable as the game itself (An event advertised at 7PM PST will most likely happen around 9PM PST)Overall, the negatives of the game really outweigh the positives of the game. But what can you expect? It's Nexon. It's a decent game to play, but if you really want to find an RPG (And I use this term very loosely for Vindictus), you're better off finding another game. I wouldn't really recommend this game to any of my friends because of the negatives of this game and the company that runs it.Edit: I will add to this, since I still do not recommend it. Vindictus is pretty much a dead game. There is little to no interaction in the game at all from other players. The only time I ever see more than one person online is either in the first 3 channels, or when an event happens. And even then, people do not interact with each other, and they go to do their own thing. The game interaction is dead, and the game itself is dead. If you want to find a game that still mimics Monster Hunter, just play Monster Hunter, this game is just a Pay to Win version of Monster Hunter.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												Let me just start by saying this is my favorite mmo. I've been playing Vindictus for almost 2 years and, despite having left a few times to try out other mmos (including the newer ones), I still can't find anything else like it.GameplayOut of all the other mmos I've played, I'd say Vindictus has the most entertaining and gratifying gameplay there is. Although it's not open world, it's easy enough to enter dungeons and raids via the dock without having to wait too long for other players to join. On the battlefield, you can dish out some pretty devastating combos, which look just as cool as they are powerful. Each class plays differently, so I'd recommend trying them out to get a feel for which one suits you best. Also, there isn't a trade system; if you want to trade with someone, you'll have to organize the details with them and send it through the mail. There's a marketplace too, if "trading" sounds like too much of a hassle, but some items may be way overpriced depending on if they're in high demand.ClassesThere are a total of 11 classes right now: 5 males and 6 females (yes, they are gender locked). Lately, it seems like they've been adding classes more frequently, so I think it's safe to say that we'll be expecting to see more in the future.CommunityThis is probably the best community I've been a part of in any game. The majority of people are quite friendly and willing to assist; I've met some pretty cool people there just by doing missions. In town, depending on what channel you're on, you may see a group of players dancing in their undies - that's normal. Basically, everyone just wants to have fun :)Other ThoughtsI see the question "Is Vindictus dead?" being asked a lot, and I'd say it's far from it. Sure, the community has gotten smaller because some players decided to play the newer mmos, but there's still quite a good amount of people left in Vindictus. With all of the events and updates going on, it seems like Vindictus has really been stepping up their game against the competition lately. I believe that in doing so, it'll bring more people back to the game, as well as attract new players. To be honest, there have been a handful of times that I "quit" the game for long periods, but there's always something that brings me back; in this case, it was the Delia update (she's awesome, by the way), so I'll probably be addicted to this game for a while...again.

												A wonderful idea, ruined by F2P cash grab mechanics in the form of extremely expensive weapon upgrades, healing potions and revive items. The grind is now quite long, and there is an almost complete lack of incentive to continue doing content that isn't top tier raid stuff for high level players, leaving the lower level group content very difficult to finish. number of helpful: 24 of 32 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
												Playing this game for a decent amount of time and progressing through much of the storyline, I can say that Vindictus has got to be one of the best MMO's I've ever played. For a F2P (Free to play) game, it has AMAZING graphics, alright storyline, vast areas to roam around, and the best part.....the Combat System. First of all, I'd like to say that there are seven classes to choose from, each with thier own unique ways of fighting and skills to perform. Why is it that so amazing? Because this Hack'n Slash has beautiful attack animations, skills and combos that are performed through right and left clicks, along with some button pressing on your keyboard, taking the concept of regular old "Press to activate skill" to an entire level. It's very easy to grasp the controls at first sight, making it an stylish, and bloody combat expereience, while other MMO's claim to boast the same things, you can most definitely expect the best combat out of Vindictus. Combat is the sole heart and soul of Vindictus. Forget everything you know about traditional MMO combat. Vindictus pushes it into real-time and amplifies it ten times. You have a regular attack and a heavy attack that can be strung together to form beautiful combos. Grabs will usually act as finishers, allowing you to smash an enemy into a wall or viciously break its back over your knee. It's this visceral brutality that makes Vindictus hard to put down.Vindictus uses Valve's Source Engine, and the result is stunning. From the tiny details of armor to the fluid animations, this is one gorgeous game to watch. Small touches, like cats and dogs scurrying about, breathe life into the city of Colhen. The same cannot always be said of the dungeons, which constantly recycle rooms from previous areas. It is not a dealbreaker, but I hope to see more variety in future updates. With the Source Engine's physics, wooden barricades can be smashed, suspended bridges can be cut and lowered, bodies crumble as they are cut down, and... certain body parts jiggle.Vindictus is truly a huge advancement in free-to-play MMOs. You'll still find a shop for purchasing or even renting outlandish outfits for real cash, but without the cut-rate gameplay and outdated graphics that most titles offer in exchange. Even with limited character-options and the lack of a sprawling world to explore, the action-packed combat of Vindictus is unrivaled in the genre.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												One of the forerunners of action based MMO, and it's still going strong with new updates coming up. If you are looking for some good solid hack and slash MMO instead of the normal click and wait ones, then this is your game. The graphics and physics of the game are awesome, and quest/storyline is well written and engaging. The combat system is innovative and continues to entertain players with new contents. The few downsides are mostly ignorable, but game does experience constant glitches and errors from update to update. Connection is troublesome as it depends on the group leader to be the host (thus the rest of the party could lag to death, speically if you fail to dodge boss attackes on time). Personally I dislike the price of the cash items in game...despite mostly cosmetic in nature, i think some utility items such as name change coupons are too overpriced. Despite the love-hate relationship, overall, Vindictus is a solid game well made.

number of helpful: 15 of 18 people (83%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
												It's a bad love/hate relationship with this one. I've played longer than the 200 hours shown on Steam, but only recently attached it to my steam account. Pros: ~Incredible combat (IT'S PRETTY F**KING EPIC REALLY) that is both satisfying and polished. Boss fights feel like boss fights, ~Good BGM, and amazing character design and customization (must be willing to spend money, although now they've added coupons and stuff from RNG boxes that could help out a bit- still must grind for gold)~Babes all over (Shayla is BAE!!!)~Guild Raids are fun [if your guild is still active kudos -_- ]Cons: ~Story line is pretty bland, the NPCs are all little PNG cutouts that you click on repeatedly and feel shallow, ~Servers are crap, it doesn't matter if you have a good computer or good internet if the person hosting a raid does not or suddenly starts lagging the entire party will suffer.This game will probably NEVER be optimized.~community is dissolving, there's no need to host a party since with the new 90 gear you can be super OP and easily solo bosses (granted that you have the skill) ~Very elitist, very grindy, very repetitive (especially if you have multiple characters), and okay graphics- you MUST be willing to deal with this if you wish to get to the good end-level stuff. Gold-sellers still plague the game even now when it's dying (Looking at some of the prices on the MP will shown why). ~VERY EXPENSIVE outfits and cash-shop items ($20-30 for a single outfit??? x however many characters you have that you want to look good) and there's RNG  where there shouldn't be RNG- in the cash-shop (stupid Dyes!!! Just give me the colors I actually want!!!). ~Enhancing (super RNG) and is enchanting is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥although now you can pay money to guarantee that Righteous or Judgement ES will work. Not to mention just how punishing a failure can be. (Poof! Any and all hard work and time put into obatining an item and it's gone- Ferghus is an A-hole)~Gearing up is a must since some people will kick you off a boat if you don't meet their desired attk reqs even if you're trying to farm the mats to reach that lvl (best to have a guild or friend to help)~Cut and paste dungeons up until you get past the second season. ~No balance in PvP whatsoever, and PvP itself is almost non-existent), not much to do after raids (Ein Lacher Challenge was recently added, but that's only for the completionists and hard-core fans- still pretty fun thou)~Updates are slow as hell, and there's a general lack of events (Christmas 2014 was the best one ever, will probably remain the only good event we've ever truly had (bring back the Christmas defense mini-game from 2011 !!!!))(10/26/2016) they added the lvl 90 mats into the seal shop, but it's a bit too late for that. (Unless you're a new player/ or you don't yet have the OJ bits you couldn't previously afford- you have it SO good RN -_-) a few months ago that would have been amazing, everyone would be all over that, but now it's more of a "meh" addition.Despite all the new additions the game is still lacking, and it's unlikely that anything "game-changing" will ever be added to it.  There's a reason(s) why the playerbase is dwindling, so when people defend it saying that it's not for the casuals, or those who don't want to spend money, or those who aren't willing to "no-life" this game they're right. At this point in time, for any new players you're gonna want to find a good guild to help you out and maybe bring a friend or two along. As it is now, only the fanboys and those who've invested a lot of time and money into this game are keeping it afloat.

number of helpful: 16 of 20 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												Welcome to the world of Nexon, where every aspect of a game is pay2win.Before I get into the negative points, I wanna say a couple words about the good stuff:-Extremely dynamic and responsive hack and slash combat system : This is not a tab-targetting/single unit combat system. It's very unique and it's very skill-based. A fraction of a second can be the deciding factor between life and death.-Awesome physics/graphics/particles/effects/etc. : Visually appealing. That's pretty much all I have to say.- Great free2play from lvl 1 to 70. Then from 70-90 its another story.Now the bad part.... -Pay2win. Did I mention pay2win? Yea pay2win by the way: Anything ranging from EXP boosts to AP boosts (This is required to lvl up Skills) to increasing enchantment success.- Bad servers : Unstable at most times but still manageable- A lot of unfixed bugs/crashes : It gets frustrating. Most of these are reported but it seems Nexon doesn't fel like fixing them.It's a great game. Great potential.... but Nexon. I feel invested in my character and the combat system is just too great for me not to play. I just get tempted a bit too much by the p2win aspect.All in all, it's worth to play for the first 70ish levels, then it becomes a grindfest for rare loot and the p2win aspect comes into play. Play at your own risk. Very addicting if you're the type of guy with some spare change.

content:
Posted: March 2
												Vindictus is a game that has been developed by devCAT and is published by Nexon... just reading this one name (Nexon of course, not devCAT) has probably made you look away already. The game has initially been released in Korea on the 21st of January 2010, whereas the North American market has only seen its release on the 13th of October 2010. If you believe that nine months later is a long time, let's not forget that the European market has discovered Vindictus on the 5th of October 2011 (so nearly a whole year later) and the Australian gamers have received this game on the 15th of November 2012 (so nearly three years after the initial release of the game in Korea).This slightly irritating bit aside, let's talk about the game itself that relies on the Source Engine produced by Valve which means that players are (supposedly) capable of interacting with their surroundings but this aspect is limited to destroying props laying around, or using them as improvised weapons. No throwing them around like you would have done so in Half-Life 2 with the Gravity Gun... and indeed I am pointing out this feature because it has been one of the major positive aspects of the Source Engine, and Half-Life 2 has exploited it amazingly in its level design whereas Vindictus simply failed to achieve the same result. Therefore, if Vindictus wanted to rely on the Source Engine to be their main selling argument... maybe, just maybe the developers should have stepped up their game to match Half-Life 2.The game offers you the "choice" between eleven Classes... which are also characters. It means that, if you want to play a Class, you have to accept (or barely tolerate) the fact that you're gender-locked and aspect-locked. Yes I did say "aspect-locked" because let's be honest, the game doesn't allow you to modify your character. If you want to play that one mountain of muscles capable of swinging a massive pillar around... it will inevitably be a beefy black man. Of course you can change the skin colour, the eyes, the eyebrows, and a few sliders for the bodyshape but all these options are severely limited and don't really allow you to deeply modify your character.The gameplay now. It is not bad at all if you love beat'm'up games such Phantasy Star Online. It relies on a simple and efficient rule : hit your enemies and do not get hit back. Oh did I say "Phantasy Star Online"? Of course I did, because this game is composed of small levels considered as one-way missions, exploration is not something the players will have to worry about because the action plays out in corridors. The only large place you will ever find is the room of the final boss! And I hope that you love loading screens, because you will see several of them.The story, since the early days of the game where it barely existed and mattered has evolved into three Seasons but the third one remains incomplete at the moment, and the second season is much shorter than the first (a prologue, ten episodes and an epilogue versus four episodes and an epilogue). So there is something to explain all the fighting, but it quicly becomes secondary once another flaw of the game hits you in the face : it is a korean game, so it involves an unhealthy amount of grinding and a ridiculous RNG that will frustrate you eventually (I should not have to fight a single Boss thirty-two times just to get a single piece of equipment, and I confirm that I did count). And quite frankly, once you reach the third Season you won't care about the story anymore because it becomes ridiculous during the Season 2, Episode 2.But maybe you'll never get to this point mainly because the first Season of Vindictus is not fun at all, and this is a fact that few players (especially the die-hard lovers of Vincdictus) will never admit. The early missions of the game have terribly aged, and Season 2 is a smelly content that will rather make you drop the game... well, if the many bugs and glitches, plus the neverending lag don't. You see, very often you will face a boss, beat him down until his body is nothing more than a fine paste, and although his health will reach the absolute zero he won't die at all. Thus you end stuck in an instance, unable to leave, and if you dare pressing Alt+F4 to quit out of desperation you shall be rewarded with a penalty for abandoning a bugged dungeon. And what about the lag you might ask? The game relies on a small software called ProudNet to establish connections between players so even there is a server to gather everyone together, instances are actually played via peer-to-peer... which means that one guy playing with a potato-powered connection will inevitably ruin the fun of everyone else. And sometimes the server itself might simply kick you out for no reason, just because it felt like doing so, forcing you to shut down the game and relaunch it in order to log back in.Now comes the technical aspect of the game. The first time I have launched this game, I clearly remember seeing a poorly textured character because the game has auto-selected the lowest graphic settings available. So I go to the Options menu in order to rectify this little mistake, move the slider all the way to "Maximum" and click "Apply"... and the game suddenly froze. Not just frozen on a frame you see, even the sound bugged out instantly and started playing the same 0.2s of an audio clip in loop as if my computer was about to experience a blue screen of death! So I press Alt+Ctrl+Suppr and properly end the process, then restart the game. Happily my settings have been saved and the game looks fantastic... but then new problems occured. Whenever I clicked a button to go to the character's creation, the sound was severely acting up, producing a loud "clic" that clearly cut off the soundtrack playing in the background. And once I eventually got the chance to play the game and reach the main hub after the tutorial... my FPS went from a mere 60 down to a pityful 19-21 just because of the many players present in the area. I will have you know and take in consideration that my computer is blessed with the power of an Intel i7-6700K plus a Nvidia GTX 1080, combined to 32Gb of RAM and a dedicated soundboard the Asus Xonar Phoebus. This game has been released in 2010, we are in 2017, and you are going to tell me that neither Nexon nor devCAT have fixed a massive memory leak and other performance-related issues in seven years? Nothing in my hardware justifies these massive and sudden FPS drops, plus the stuttering sound whenever there's a loading screen or an action-packed scene going on.As a matter of fact, I do not recommand this game at all to anyone. And I have not even talked about the Cash Shop that is nothing more than a glorified lotery at every level beginning at 4€ / $4 without any explaination for such high entry price, or the Enhancing & Enchanting systems that can (and often will) break your hard-earned gear regardless of its rarity (reaching the +10 is the most risky thing you will ever do in this game, just staring at it will give you cold sweat). I am not telling you to avoid this game at all cost, because it is a fun game to play... but you will have to look past all the aforementioned flaws in order to get any degree of fun out of it.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2016
												I've been playing this game for a long time over the years, it's always been fun for me and friends. Many people will say the company is greedy for money and the game is boring, but the company who develops the game actually updates it with a lot of events and content, including new characters, seasonal events, and player appreciation events as well as beginner events for new players. While people may say it's very pay 2 win, most paid things are cosmetic and only help a bit like a pet or maybe some quick health potions, most paid things still won't beat good old skill though. Paying can give you some small advantages however that has virtually no effect on other players as the game is PvE based, so don't worry about someone else paying affecting you. My only problem is the early game can lack a little bit, but the later game is great, the longer you play the better it gets (and the bosses get hella bigger too) So if i'm to recommend this game, i'd say grab a couple friends, sit down and enjoy it however you want,  learn some skills, play some events, and remember, the more you play the better it gets. Have fun.
