content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												I’ve been experimenting with the MMO genre lately. Most games I tried would procure a couple hours of fun after which I would quit. The reason for this: I felt like I was wasting my time. Contrarily to popular belief, Video games don’t usually give me that feeling. I needed something better than your typical MMORPG with a failed plot and little replay value. I needed a game that felt... I don’t know, like more than just a game. I found it. If the title didn’t give it away, I’m talking about Vindictus. Vindictus is an MMO that combines your typical RPG experience with a hack n slash feel, impressive visuals, lush and varied environments, a good story and an insane replay value only to name a few aspects. The community is amazing and the huge 18 player team battles with make this game seem unreal. In short, Vindictus is exactly what I was looking for. Vindictus is more than just a game.Vindictus runs on Valve’s source engine. Nexon (the studio behind the game) probably picked this engine to allow extreme interaction between the player and the world. Past games like Half-Life 2 and Portal can testify to the awesomeness of this engine. Needless to say Nexon made a great choice. Contrarily to most online multiplayer games, the world behind Vindictus actually feels alive. Picking up, throwing and smashing objects around feels perfect. When I throw a wooden barrel into the ocean, the barrel sinks then resurfaces and floats. IT DOESN’T DISAPPEAR. The physics engine is out of this world.The story is interesting enough. There are a couple cut scenes coupled with dialogue that may or may not entice you to read more of it. I have to say that the dialogue is actually pretty good and I often find myself wondering what’s going to happen. This is one of the rare aspects that Vindictus does not excel in. Moving on to the online part of the game, it‘s crazy how fun this game is to play with friends. Before starting it, I suggest you find 2 or 3 friends and start it all together, because all 3 of you will have a blast. Everything in this game can be done in teams, and as I said earlier the big team battles against seemingly invincible bosses are something you will be talking about in the morning.    Earlier I mentioned the environments. They’re epic. I mean really epic. You go from fighting vampires in a pillaged town to fighting mummies on desert dunes only to end up with reapers in a dark crypt. Jungles, deserted plains, tropical islands, ancient ruins; this game has it all. The monsters themselves have amazing sprites that could easily be compared to a triple A game such as Skyrim. Each mission ends with a boss fight, usually a great boss fight. Beating bosses is easy once you understand their attack pattern, at least early on. All you Sword Art Online fans will feel right at home, but let’s not get into that.    Now I think it’s time we talk about the combat. There are about 8 different characters in Vindictus, each one having a unique and interesting combat style. Whether you want to shoot from a distance, cast fireballs, or leap into the fray with a giant pillar, there’s a combat style for you. My first character was Vella. A girl that dual wields either swords or chain blades. The former allows you to slice n dice from close range while the latter allows you to rip through enemies from far away. Every character has 2 weapons like this. Considering this, we can safely confirm that you can fight through this game in 16 different ways. I used twin blades with Vella. Once you’ve chosen a weapon. You can unlock abilities both passive and active as you progress through the game. For instance, when you start playing, the shift button activates a dash. Level up enough and you can unlock the Slipaway ability, letting you jump back while cutting anyone around you for some very handsome damage. Double tapping shift will activate this and pressing it a third time will throw in a dash to the combo. Very useful for escapes, making Vella an agile fighter if need be (extremely useful against bosses). Other abilities, such as Cross Cut will let you run right through an enemy attack if timed perfectly.Character customization is always important in an RPG. Vindictus once again makes me drool with insane skins and armour, making this dark themed, possibly depressing concept into something quite enjoyable to look at. This being said, many decorative aspects of the game require that you pay, but its player versus monster nature makes these things not an issue.There is PVP, although you will have to play for a while before experiencing it. All I can say for now is that I have noticed a rock paper scissor effect between certain characters. If you’re looking for a PVP heavy game, Vindictus is not what you’re looking for.Continuing on a sour note, you need a computer with dedicated graphics and a broadband internet connection to pull this game off. Or else the lag will probably kill it for you. Reflecting on this, anyone who doesn’t have dedicated graphics should probably not be on Steam, although you can play Vindictus without a Steam account. I haven’t covered everything, because that would take forever, but I feel as I’ve given you enough that you can decide whether or not to give this game a shot. Good luck!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												I have to be honest. My initial thoughts of this game were pretty negative.  There are some things that I do not like about the game, but the positives far outway the negatives.  I'll start with the negatives. I'm not a fan of the way the story progression is set up. It's like a flashback to an old school RPG before character animations and voice acting was implemented.  I don't like having to read the dialogue from a tiny box next to a portrait of an anime character.  It can be pretty boring... which is why I have almost no idea what the storyline is about. It just doesn't keep my attention, so I end up skipping a lot of the dialogue.  Also, the character customization is extremely basic.  I expected quite a bit more, but was disappointed. It is possible to get better hair cuts, costumes, dyes, and armor, but it will cost you quite a bit of real life money. Needless to say, I'm not interested in paying money for in game underwear.  Lastly, I don't much care for the way the quests are set up.  It's not open world, which is kind of lame, so questing is different in this game. Each battle (this is what the quests/missions are called in game) is like a mini-dungeon that is replayable. It's replayable because each battle has a list of achievement-like side quests.  These reward you with gold and experience when you complete them.  So this is a completionists worst nightmare, or wet dream... I could see an argument for both.  None of the battles are too tough, even on hard mode, to finish alone, but the raids require a little more muscle.  So the positives.  The game looks decent enough. The graphics aren't spectacular, but they did a good job on the characters' looks. Especially the female characters. They look pretty damn great. The female characters' costumes would fit perfectly into every nerdy teenage boy's hentai fantasy.  The combat is pretty cool.  It took a little getting used to initially, but once I got it down, I liked it. It's a little big buggy at times when it comes to the dodging and parrying against enemies, but still a lot of fun. It sort of reminds me of Dynasty Warriors back in the day.  You know, before they made 57 remakes.  Overall, it is a pretty fun game. Definitely worth trying if you're even a little bit interested. Plus, its free. How the hell can you pass up trying a free game?  GET THIS GAME.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												Vindictus is a game that can be both enjoyable and challenging, but can also be tedious and long. The first couple of levels are a cake walk. You start out with the basic skills and equipment and as you further move along the game, you gain more points for skills, random weapon/equipment drops fit for your current level, and in-game money for future spending. This stage of the game is easy and can be finished, solo with little effort. However, as the levels get harder and the bosses get bigger (polar bears to trolls to wolves to dragons to demons), more effort is needed to continue further. Solo is pretty much gone unless you're a high enough level and have high tier equipment. But at this stage, team work and the in-game market come into play. You will need other people to play with to complete the oncoming barrage of difficult levels and the Market in-game is needed to get more powerful and resilient equipment (in-game money used). So if communication and grinding aren't your thing, Vindictus' mid-late and late game will not be for you. However, with enough hard work and dedication, you can be a hulking image in Vindictus with no real life money spent whatsoever. Vindictus trully is a game for the dedicated and skilled.-Yumi

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												My previous review was negative and it remains negative for anyone having the annoying "BlackCipher" glitch while using Windows 10. For people like me, I had to revert my Windows back to 8.1 to play, and I know that this sounds insane just to play 1 game. The only reason I did this was I had very high hopes for this game. Was it worth it? Well you probably know the answer to that just by the rating of this review. This game has a lot to offer and I am barely so far scratching the surface for this game. This game feels like a game I would be willing to pay retail price for, but of course it is free. The number one question people always ask though is "Is it P2W?" My answer to this is no. The only thing I would recommend paying for is the .99 starter pack for it is one hell of a deal and makes low level leveling easier if you are by yourself. Other then that you can pay for cosmetics and let me just say the cosemetics range from really scimpy or cute to full blown f*cking awesome! So unless you want to pay for some of the costumes this game is fair and balanced in combat. Combat is awesome because I have never met a game where you can just grab a enemy and use the enviroment to kill him. These kills range from Sparta kicking some one of a cliff to body slamming them on a pile of rubble. Think of this game as a beat them up with very hard but rewarding boss fights. The only thing I could say that has been annoying so far is the random bots who stand in town and advertise their account stealing websites. Do not trust these sights because they just hijack your account. These bots are always being activley banned, but not quick enough. Other then that this game is a blast and there is NO reason you shouldn't give it a try! Also last thing is this game is optimized REALLY well. I don't have the best computer but I still get 60FPS on medium graphics, Have fun!Edit: Radi boss waiting times are stupid long. I know this isn't the games fault, but it still sucks.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												I decided to try this game on a whim because of some of the reviews but upon further inspection i realize I may be late to this party. I rolled on the US East server, there were 3 choices, US East, US West, and Aus i think? Well here has been my experience playing to level 20. The thing that got me playing at all was the character cuztomization, This is a decent system and i like the diferent looks and possibilities however. Each class is gender locked which to me seems sounter productive. So if I want to play as a sorceress i must choose "evie" who is female. I can then alter her look however i wish. My question is why gender lock the roles? Now this doens't bother me as i like sorcerers and female avatars but i know some people would be put off by this. Such as if you wish to play the ranger class you must pick a male avatar. etc etc.  Pro: You can alter your character to look pretty much any way you desire, Con: Gender locking classesRedundancy.In order to do quests you have to get them from npcs of course then you must locate the battle board to select a dungeon you wish to do.  Then you either join a part who is waiting in the staging area. A rarity i am sure, or create your own party and invite whoever you like. Then you board the boat and see the same dramatic heroic scene reminiscent of soul calibur and off you go , each area has dungeons that look exactly the same. You may go through 10 dungeons that all are nearly identical but rearranged to fight red name bosses and win the day. then back to town. Rinse and repeat. This has become.. redundant. Population, Seems very low. The starting area "colhen" looks populated but that's as far as it goes. If you decide to venture out to the other few areas of the game where high level players should be doing their thing you'll find a ghost town. This is a shame because now i feel put off form bothering. It appears that everyone just hangs out on colhen. There isn;t a whol elot to ehis game.Raids. Seems easy to be called raids. I did a raid on the first available raid dungeon with two friends. They died relatively fast but i managed ot finish the boss by myself. Wasn't too difficult even on hard mode. Rewards weren't great either. I imagine these do get harder as you progress if you do that is.All in all i am not ready to quit the game as of yet so I will keep leveling and seeing what else the game has to offer. mainly because i have nothing better to do these days. Going to recommend the game so more people play it because it seems the only major thing lacking is population. Seems to be a big trend with mmos these days. Shame really. Will update this again another time.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Vindictus is a game sort of like Warframe if you've played the game, you would already know the feel of a third person action RPG. While Warframe is set in the future, Vindictus is set in medieval times. It has a varierty of characters for different people with different tastes, there's a tank named Karok who can protect his team and also has a decent amount of burst damage, a mage named Evie who can both do insane damage with a scythe & offensive magic while also helping the team with buffs and revives, then for those who prefer a mix of both defensive and offensive there's Fiona, a wielder of sword and shield who can block the enemy's attacks and send forth her own counter attacks to deal out decent burst damage, then comes Kai, an archer who prefers kiting the enemy rather than going ham who wields both rapidfire Crossbow like gun, and a slower but more hard hitting bow which can be transformed in the middle of combat from a longbow to a shortbow whether you need better fire rate or more range and can find the enemy's weakpoint and use it to temporarily stun them and deal bonus damage. Then there is Lann and Vella, while both wield dual swords, Lann can wield dual spears, while Vella can wield dual Chainblades (the damn thing has HUGE range) and both can offer different skills while still offer speedy gameplay. Finally there is Hurk, the beserker, he focuses on constant AOE while also using skills to attack endlessly, ignore CC, restore health, and if you have good timing, you can even deflect the boss's attacks and counter attack to CC the boss and deal huge damage. Now some of you may be thinking of the community, but don't fret the community is both funny and helpful by helping new players finish missions which would normally be too difficult to overcome. While others may be too lazy to bother leveling up at such a slow pace, do not even worry about it. You'll get into mid game faster than you will think. The only problem I've had with this game is the constant upgrading of gear and finding the right build paths to maximize overall effctiveness throughout the game as well as the rather ludicrous pricing on premium items as well as the 2x exp VIP bonuses. Overall, I've had a lot of fun in this game and I recommend this for anyone who likes RPG's and can deal with a slow start for a faster paced and challenging mid-late game where personal player skills will be tested.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												Only played long enough to get to level 3, the game looks GREAT, it really does. But i was immediately put off by a couple of things.Cons: Story Progression is done in a way most MMORPG players are not used to, as in the dialogue boxes and chat with npc's is very different from a traditional MMORPG. This is a detail that i think the veteran MMO players would find slightly frustrating, but maybe they would have the patience to let it grow on them. I however, found it very off putting.Some weapons / classes are only available to certain genders. You pick a base character / hero at the very beginning, and you can tweak them later as far as physical appearance is concerned, and your name of course. But all of them use only one type of weapon, so if you want to use a glaive for instance, you are FORCED to play as a female character. Or if you want to use a great sword, you are FORCED to play a male character. Again, this may not matter for some, but to me  as a Veteran MMORPG player again this was off putting. I havn't even made it past character creation and my freedom is already being restricted? Not a good development choice.Character creation is a bit lacking, there are some features that you can only use by acquiring items from the in game cash shop, and other features are just badly implimented (The sliders for fat/muscle imparticular feel bad / inaccurate)Pros: The game looks beautifulCombat seems pretty fluid

												Has a great fighting style and easy to follow questline. Definitely recommended if you're willing to slash through dungeons. Some parts of the game may get repetitive but it's all in good fun. Not as P2W as most Nexon games are, eg. Maplestory. - 10 year Maplestory Veteran

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												My previous review was negative and it remains negative for anyone having the annoying "BlackCipher" glitch while using Windows 10. For people like me, I had to revert my Windows back to 8.1 to play, and I know that this sounds insane just to play 1 game. The only reason I did this was I had very high hopes for this game. Was it worth it? Well you probably know the answer to that just by the rating of this review. This game has a lot to offer and I am barely so far scratching the surface for this game. This game feels like a game I would be willing to pay retail price for, but of course it is free. The number one question people always ask though is "Is it P2W?" My answer to this is no. The only thing I would recommend paying for is the .99 starter pack for it is one hell of a deal and makes low level leveling easier if you are by yourself. Other then that you can pay for cosmetics and let me just say the cosemetics range from really scimpy or cute to full blown f*cking awesome! So unless you want to pay for some of the costumes this game is fair and balanced in combat. Combat is awesome because I have never met a game where you can just grab a enemy and use the enviroment to kill him. These kills range from Sparta kicking some one of a cliff to body slamming them on a pile of rubble. Think of this game as a beat them up with very hard but rewarding boss fights. The only thing I could say that has been annoying so far is the random bots who stand in town and advertise their account stealing websites. Do not trust these sights because they just hijack your account. These bots are always being activley banned, but not quick enough. Other then that this game is a blast and there is NO reason you shouldn't give it a try! Also last thing is this game is optimized REALLY well. I don't have the best computer but I still get 60FPS on medium graphics, Have fun!Edit: Radi boss waiting times are stupid long. I know this isn't the games fault, but it still sucks.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												I decided to try this game on a whim because of some of the reviews but upon further inspection i realize I may be late to this party. I rolled on the US East server, there were 3 choices, US East, US West, and Aus i think? Well here has been my experience playing to level 20. The thing that got me playing at all was the character cuztomization, This is a decent system and i like the diferent looks and possibilities however. Each class is gender locked which to me seems sounter productive. So if I want to play as a sorceress i must choose "evie" who is female. I can then alter her look however i wish. My question is why gender lock the roles? Now this doens't bother me as i like sorcerers and female avatars but i know some people would be put off by this. Such as if you wish to play the ranger class you must pick a male avatar. etc etc.  Pro: You can alter your character to look pretty much any way you desire, Con: Gender locking classesRedundancy.In order to do quests you have to get them from npcs of course then you must locate the battle board to select a dungeon you wish to do.  Then you either join a part who is waiting in the staging area. A rarity i am sure, or create your own party and invite whoever you like. Then you board the boat and see the same dramatic heroic scene reminiscent of soul calibur and off you go , each area has dungeons that look exactly the same. You may go through 10 dungeons that all are nearly identical but rearranged to fight red name bosses and win the day. then back to town. Rinse and repeat. This has become.. redundant. Population, Seems very low. The starting area "colhen" looks populated but that's as far as it goes. If you decide to venture out to the other few areas of the game where high level players should be doing their thing you'll find a ghost town. This is a shame because now i feel put off form bothering. It appears that everyone just hangs out on colhen. There isn;t a whol elot to ehis game.Raids. Seems easy to be called raids. I did a raid on the first available raid dungeon with two friends. They died relatively fast but i managed ot finish the boss by myself. Wasn't too difficult even on hard mode. Rewards weren't great either. I imagine these do get harder as you progress if you do that is.All in all i am not ready to quit the game as of yet so I will keep leveling and seeing what else the game has to offer. mainly because i have nothing better to do these days. Going to recommend the game so more people play it because it seems the only major thing lacking is population. Seems to be a big trend with mmos these days. Shame really. Will update this again another time.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												Vindictus is a game that can be both enjoyable and challenging, but can also be tedious and long. The first couple of levels are a cake walk. You start out with the basic skills and equipment and as you further move along the game, you gain more points for skills, random weapon/equipment drops fit for your current level, and in-game money for future spending. This stage of the game is easy and can be finished, solo with little effort. However, as the levels get harder and the bosses get bigger (polar bears to trolls to wolves to dragons to demons), more effort is needed to continue further. Solo is pretty much gone unless you're a high enough level and have high tier equipment. But at this stage, team work and the in-game market come into play. You will need other people to play with to complete the oncoming barrage of difficult levels and the Market in-game is needed to get more powerful and resilient equipment (in-game money used). So if communication and grinding aren't your thing, Vindictus' mid-late and late game will not be for you. However, with enough hard work and dedication, you can be a hulking image in Vindictus with no real life money spent whatsoever. Vindictus trully is a game for the dedicated and skilled.-Yumi

												So I needed to remake my "Nexon ID password" to log in, and after I log in and it looks like everything is fine, I am confronted with a screen that wants me to make a "secondary passwoird" and how it's worded, it sounds like it is optional, so I close the window and I'm brought back to the main menu. My first thought was "Well F2P games can be buggy, maybe it didn't realize that I just wanted to play the game." So I clicked on start game again, and it brought me to the same secondary password menu. At this point I pressed Alt+F4 to close the game and remove it from my library forever. I would not recommend Vindictus because I don't care nearly enough to make and remember two passwords for a free to play game, and I urge you not to as well.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2012
												Edit: 6/4/2014There's been alot of changes since my post in 2012. Most of what I stated before is still somewhat the same, but....Nexon has once again practically ruined a game. Though Vindictus itself is still a load of fun and very skill oriented, Nexon has made some incredibly confusing and worrisome decisions. For one, they totally removed Jumping from the game. Now, Jumping in itself wasn't very well implemented. But instead of fixing it, they opted to delete it completely...which means all of the Season 2 maps that incorporated jumping mechanics, as well as Season 2 enemies that forced you to use Jumping to either kill them or dodge their attacks, have been totally reworked and, quite frankly, boring-ified. Now every enemy, though with different tactics and timing, all are dumbed down and simplified from before. Definitely a bad, bad change in my opinion.Also, as for this game not being Pay2Win... It's slowly but surely becoming exactly that. You can buy cash accesories that give notable bonuses to stats, pets that do the same, and if you want to succeed in very high level play, you're definitely going to need to use a huge amount of ingame currency to strengthen your weapons, and then buy Runes to + them past +6. Infact, you're going to want +10 or higher weapons to be helpful in a group.Anyway, that's my update. This game will forever hold a candle in my heart, but...*sigh* Nexon. Nexon strikes again. I still recommend it, but going higher than level 70 will be...very frustrating for most players.There's a review by v0!dsnak3 that points out other problems perfectly, and ALL not due to the game itself, but because of Nexon being the way they are. Money grubbing event tactics, horrible events in general that focus more on cash players than free players...The list goes on. I suggest reading his/her review, as they nailed it on the head. (They gave Vin a thumbs down, which I have to say I agree with)I'll keep my original review here as well. -------------------------------------------Been playing this game ever since it was released a good 2 or so years ago. It's ALOT of fun, but needs more exposure and advertising! Thankfully they finally brought it here to Steam for more people to enjoy. This Free2Play is centered mostly around dungeons instances. It's one of the rare few F2P games that is NOT Pay2Win!! It's more Pay4Convienience and Pay4Customization. Most of the money you'll probably spend on this game is for "Inner Armors" or underwear that give no extra stats, but makes your character look good. There's also hairstyles, tattoos, makeup, facial hair, etc. Admittedly without paying, you will only be able to pick hairstyles, skin color (a large palette), hair color, eye color, and eyebrow color. Still, not bad for a FREE game when it comes to customization.This game, like I said before, is NOT pay2win. It focuses on Skill2Win and Gear2Win. You actually need to learn how your enemies attack, and get a feel for your character. Seriously, try this game out!!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												This game is so boring. It is a repetitive mess in all of its levels. My friend says it stops getting repetitive once you reach a certain level. NO!! The game should have not been repetitive at all!! The levels should have been interesting and cool from the start, but they all suck.What it is like getting my 50th mission in this game.Gwyn: "Kill this minster for me."I look at the monster, it is a clone of a clone, of a clone. The bosses are the same and all the developers did was make them bigger or changed the color of them. And it is usually like that in any level.Now there are bosses at the end of the world(area...i don't know) that are interesting, but the game has to keep me interested because going through the levels to get to the final boss of the world is so boring!The only fun things for me to do in this game is this labyrinth, raids, and this boss rush like area(it is in a desert I believe). I can't do a lot of raids and trying to get into a group raid takes forever.I also want to say something about the missions in the game. They suck and for one reason only. Not the repetitiveness of them, the level requirements. I should be able to do the mission without needing that level to do the mission. This forces me to grind, and yes I know. There is grinding in other mmo, but I don't grind as much in those than I do in Vindictus. It forces me to grind and that adds more to the repetitiveness of the game.Now I like repetitive games, only if they keep my interest. Monster Hunter and Warframe come to mind. Monster Hunter has bosses that I would like to fight over and over because I want a cool armor piece and they are fun to battle. Warframe is very repetitive, but the gunplay is great, Warframe abilities are nice, and some of the missions are fun. Going through different waves of enemies, I like that. Killing all the enemies in an area, I like that. Vindictus is just run through different areas, kill the boss of the level(the boss looks like every other boss) and done. Nothing interesting at all, no random events. Nothing. Just more trolls and worms with teeth that come out of the ground.I can touch on how bland the game looks, but it is an old game after all. The portraits of characters are decent. This game is just boring though. It cannot keep my attention at all. I do not understand why my Friend likes this game so much. I told him that he would really love Monster Hunter, and he saw you had to eat to keep your stamina up. He doesn't like it because you have to eat. He is an idiot because you don't have to eat a lot. Just eat before a mission and you are all good. The only times you might need to eat is when you die because your stamina goes back to normal, but it is still manageable stamina to work with.That's it. If you love this game, good for you, keep playing it. Me on the other hand, I do not like it. I am level 47 and nothing interesting has happened yet. I am warning anyone else who gets this boring game.Now it is free, so people can download it to try it, but why wait for a boring game  to download?

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												**Disclaimer: This is going to sound like a negative review, but hopeful.**Vindictus is an awesome MMO that combines the crafting and big bosses of Monster Hunter with the Hack n' Slash style of gameplay. I just wish it was run by a better company...but more on that later. Just bear with me on this one and remember that despite its flaws (mainly Nexon's fault) I still love Vindictus. My advice to you: find a group of friends--maybe even people you know IRL--and plow through the whole thing together. You'll have a blast.I'll save the lengthy review for after the pros/cons.Pros:--Hack n' Slash action combined with Monster Hunter crafting!! All gear is crafted from materials dropped by slain enemies, and the best gear is made from the stuff you collect from [raid] bosses--Player crafting TRULY allows you to make the best gear in the game. There are no raid-exclusive items you can't craft at the max crafting level. However, it is a HUGE time sink to get to max level (I know from experience).--EnCHANTment system adds another level to make your gear even more badass--Raid bosses can be an outstanding team experience--24-player raid battles >:O Vs. DRAGONS >>:O~~~ <--fire breath--Break-off system (detailed above)--Characters <3--Free to play!Cons:--Nexon (see below)--EnHANCEment system risks breaking your weapon!! (up to +10 you're safe) Honestly, I wouldn't view this as a bad thing if item drops weren't so lousy...oh yeah, the drop rate!--Drop rates are complete BS (i.e. 1/1000 chance of getting a rare drop from most raid bosses and remember crafting is drop-dependent!)--Stats beat skill (with the best gear anyone can be god-like)--VERY MUCH pay to win :( Although you can still have an enjoyable time F2P--Peer-to-peer connections make everybody unhappy (if host's internet sucks)--THE GRIND!!Neutral:--No open-world--Missions are pretty repetitive--Inflation means the market sucks--BotsA word on Nexon:My fellow reviewers have said Nexon makes EA look good. Their customer support is almost non-existent, the servers are run by hamsters and yes sometimes one of those hamsters dies (which explains the random disconnects encountered quite frequently), and yes some of the bugs which were around from the very beginning still have not been fixed. I've been playing since the open beta so I can confirm that last one...some game company seriously needs to forcibly acquire Vindictus and bring out its full potential! I'm looking at you NCsoft/ArenaNet!!The gameplay is fantastic. If you like the hack n' slash genre you will love Vindictus. Adding to your basic combos is your secondary weapons (spears, chain hooks, etc.) which fulfill a support-type function on missions. Spears can be used to stagger the boss or break-off certain parts of the boss' armor/weapon/body. Chain hooks are primarily used to slow down or entirely restrict the movement of the boss allowing your party to lay on some serious hurt or giving your spear-throwers an easy shot for that break-off. Going into more detail on the break-off system, some bosses have one or more specific areas you can attack and, after repeated successful blows, break off in order to obtain a special material (i.e. one boss is a mammoth and you can break off its tusks--a vital material for that boss' weapon/armor set) and other bonuses (i.e. destroying a part of their armor causes them to take more damage, and destroying their weapon removes certain attacks from their moveset or simply weakens their attack damage/range overall).Missions are done in the following structure: You get on a boat setting up all the criteria (mission, difficulty, number of players, etc.) which is Lobbying 101 and then, when you and your party are ready (you can solo), a loading screen takes you to the dungeon. Your objective is to kill all enemies in order to progress to the boss room where you're in for a truly EPIC fight. Each boss has its own attack pattern and skills and presents a unique challenge in its own right. Raid bosses are even more amazing--terrifying and powerful both in size and the challenge they present. Some require teamwork, which is lousy if you've got a troll or newbie on your team, but worthwhile and fun if everyone is informed. Some of the things Nexon has done with these raid bosses are truly brilliant :D In one fight you push rocks over a ledge to knock out a mammoth for a few precious moments while your teammates below pile on the damage, and in a different fight you throw holy spears at the feet of an angry demon god-cow-thing in order to pin him in place. In another you fire ballistae at a dragon IN-FLIGHT in order to shoot him out of the air!! SERIOUSLY HOW COOL IS THAt?!Additionally, there is both an enCHANTment and enHANCEment system. The enHANCEment system is your basic weapon/armor upgrades from +1 to +15 which improve the item's stats. The enCHANTment system is more in-depth. First you must find the specfic scrolls you are looking for and the necessary materials for enchantment (these materials are all hard to come by, but if you are aiming for the end-game you'll put in the effort). There are prefix and suffix scrolls meaning each piece of gear can have two enchantments.Oh yeah, and people say the story is good, but I must not have been paying attention. There are some pretty memorable characters, although I'm glad Ellis is dead xD

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												After about five hours of actual playtime, I can say several things about the game: First, it has a lot of potential. Second, it doesn't use all of it. Most of the actual mmo part didnt really stand out to me, I never saw a party appear on the board, I never felt connected to other players. Gameplay was fun at first, then slowly became repetitive. Go to ruins, fight same generic monsters, fight slightly different boss, feel like you're missing something the whole time. Maybe you'll find it interesting, and it's a way to pass the time for sure, but as a main MMO to invest hours in, I don't recommend it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												This game is actually pretty good for an MMO. Previously I had had problems with the game starting altogether, but of course that was about 2 years ago which was probably my bad. But continuing all around it's a good game I enjoy it I would have to give it a 9/10 at least I found it to be impressive for a FTP a couple things are a little wonky but I hope that they get fixed in the near furture. For example I was playing with a friend and he decided to give me some stuff and when I went to open the gift in the mailbox (note that I was on channel 117 on the east coast servers) the entire game just crashes on me and the gift file that was sent to me still remains corrupted as of right now (I say this because when my friend tried to cancel it gift it crashed his game as well may of been server issues, it may of been client issues, I don't really know right now but I can say for sure it was irritating). Now that may be irritating to deal with but seriously it's an MMO, since when have MMO's ever been perfect there are always going to be problems with the game that require constant patches and updates in order to make sure people actually play it and don't get frustrated and just quit. That's especially true when with games such as this one, where it's a constantly updating game which is good in some cases but bad in others. Over all with the ocasional glitches and what not it is a really good Free to Play game that is well worth the time (even though I haven't spent alot of time on the game), again I would give this a 9/10 because it's still has it's bugs which downgrade the games quality but doesn't downgrade it enough for it to be a complete waste of coding.On a side note, if you have a really bad computer that can't run high quality games such as World of Tanks, Red Orchestra 2 or any high graphics and processor intensive game (my laptop for example HP Pavilion G62 running at 2.13 GHz in processor speed with 4 GB of RAM and an Intel intergrated graphics card) then do exercise some caution with the game and make sure you have your game settings set down to minimum if your computer is like mine because if you don't have the bare minimun requirements, then good luck playing it but for me if I set all my settings to low then the frames cap at about 67 FPS and mediate at about 55 FPS which is really good I might add. Even then putting you settings on low, the game still looks really good. So deffinetly check to see if you computer or laptop is able to run it and if so have fun gamming cause I know what I'm going to be doing a lot this summer after getting of work....dungeon raids with friends.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												I'm not gonna give you a full breakdown of pros and cons for this game. There are plenty of detailed reviews already that both recommend and don't recommend Vindictus.Plain and simple: You play it for the combat. For me that was enough. The combat is what I've always wanted to see in any mmo. That alone will determine if you stick with the game or not. Sure there is a lot wrong with the game, bugs and such. Nexon sucks at their job, players are questionable at high levels, peer-to-peer sucks, grind grind grind, all that good stuff. I generally play solo on missions, so I dont have to deal with player and connection issues. To avoid the grind the best thing I can say is don't play as much. Take breaks, make new characters, go play something else for awhile. I tend to play for a time, then stop playing long enough to where I get free gift bag with armor and xp boosts when I return.So, try it for the combat, it's hack and slash after all. Who doesn't like hack and slash?!

Your objective is to kill all enemies in order to progress to the boss room where you're in for a truly EPIC fight. Each boss has its own attack pattern and skills and presents a unique challenge in its own right. Raid bosses are even more amazing--terrifying and powerful both in size and the challenge they present. Some require teamwork, which is lousy if you've got a troll or newbie on your team, but worthwhile and fun if everyone is informed. Some of the things Nexon has done with these raid bosses are truly brilliant :D In one fight you push rocks over a ledge to knock out a mammoth for a few precious moments while your teammates below pile on the damage, and in a different fight you throw holy spears at the feet of an angry demon god-cow-thing in order to pin him in place. In another you fire ballistae at a dragon IN-FLIGHT in order to shoot him out of the air!! SERIOUSLY HOW COOL IS THAt?!Additionally, there is both an enCHANTment and enHANCEment system. The enHANCEment system is your basic weapon/armor upgrades from +1 to +15 which improve the item's stats. The enCHANTment system is more in-depth. First you must find the specfic scrolls you are looking for and the necessary materials for enchantment (these materials are all hard to come by, but if you are aiming for the end-game you'll put in the effort). There are prefix and suffix scrolls meaning each piece of gear can have two enchantments.Oh yeah, and people say the story is good, but I must not have been paying attention. There are some pretty memorable characters, although I'm glad Ellis is dead xD

content:
Posted: June 27, 2012
												Pretty bangin' smash 'em up MMORPG. Runs off source engine, maps are small but load times are usually pretty short. The game has a lot of character to it - its best feature. Classes are really fun to play. The game is originally Korean and is a bit 'kawaii desu' but was ported to American. Really awesome crafting system for armor (and I'd mention armor usually looks pretty sick and unique) and players generally have the option to play solo or with a group. Really under-rated in my opinion. Though the game has a cash shop, its main purpose is aesthetics and health/XP/life boosters. Can be repetitive but generally action-packed though the story could be sharper.

Played well before it was out on steam (Only 3 characters to choose from! It was horrible!). It can get old after about a month of hacking, slashing, and blowing things up. content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												A highly addictive MMORPG that incorporates true hack and slash gameplay to create a unique experience unlike every other MMO outside of Gunz.  Characterization is highly customizable, including and not limited to cash-store items and items found and purchased in-game.  Market for items is fairly standard and also highly robust, meaning story related items can be purchased if you have the gold on you.  Community is fairly nice and well-meaning.  Alot of active players to facilitate anyone looking to teamup and play with other people right from the get-go.  Graphics, story, gameplay and an active community contribute to what is an overall solid game that is more than worth the time to download.  Free to play is probably the biggest draw!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Vindictus is a fun, entertaining hack & slash with memorable bosses and great gameplay. Unfortunately the game falls a bit short in its story, leveling, and high level community.Without spoiling anything, the story is extremely cheesy with unlikable characters who you just grow to hate. There aren't any redeeming qualities about the characters even when the developers try to force it upon you.The leveling gets very grindy really quick, unless you are willing to invest a few dollars into VIP services or you manage to happen upon one from a level up gift / special event.The high level community are pretty toxic, to the point that they won't even consider you if you don't have specific stats for your chosen character. If you didn't place your stats rights you are out of luck unless you are willing to invest some money into AP resets.Other than those fallbacks, the gameplay is still entertaining, addicting and worth the playtime.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												If I were to say anything about Vindictus is that it has the most intense combat of any free-to-play MMORPG out there. Take note: This game is not an open world experience, and can be summed up as an Instance run extravaganza. Every mission is just another instance. But don't let that discourage you. It is definitely a fun game. And while the only things that cost money are the cosmetic and inventory expansions, its a fair trade. No pay to win here. I've never dwelled on the PVP portions of the game but it is truly an experience best done with friends. Guild Bonuses are fun to work towards and the best thing about this game, is that if you are not one to play constantly, no problem. Once you get your character past the tutorial stuff, you can leave him be for months while he accumulates points to put towards leveling individual skills. Also note that these skills do have level caps so there it is not possible for a lvl 10 character to max out. But it's a nice feature to have, especially if you don't like grinding for points. Bottom line, it's a great beat em up experience that I'd highly recommend if you love action RPG's.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2012
												Vinductus is a fun, action packed, mmo that you can play with your friends for hours. The world is a dark place filled with monsters and little hope. To start off you must choose from one of five characters: Kai - ranger, Karok - brutish offensive tank, fiona - the defensive tank, lann - using dual weapons for lethal combos and evie the mage.Over all this is an extremly fun game and since it's free to play i reccomend giving it a try. The game does get a little repetetive especially since you have to repeat some of the same quests over and over for different tasks though thats the only downside I see.There is a level system, 70 being the highest and you achieve AP through battlequests (dungeons) that you use to upgrade your skills.

												Ok so vindictus is really rewarding in the combat system its fluid, hard, and satisfying, the artistry and overall look of the game is very pretty for a free to  play game along with is interesting enemies and bosses. Bosses the threshold between being new to the game and being a vet of it changes very drastically, I was soloing everything till about lvl 25 and then bosses became incredibly strong and hard to beat unless you have a team in hard mode but normal is still pretty easy. Crafting and money go hand in hand in vidictus you need money to craft but you can sell everything for a lot on the Auction house. The only problem i have with the game is the fact you have to farm a lot of training points and materials and when I mean a lot, I mean an♥♥♥♥♥ton unless you have a group and farm hard mode. Overall the game is pretty the combat is amazing and the difficulty scales fast (which i love :).) I have had a wonderful expierence playing this game and i hope you guys come join me in the chao :)

content:
Posted: September 4, 2012
												In this free-to-play game, you can purchase bikinis and underwear (at around US$10) for your female character to run around in while she slaps a gnoll against a wall and then drives her elbow in with crushing force.While that sounds like a nice beat'em-up thing to do, the Korean grind seeps in as you repeat missions to gain experience or objective points to unlock the next mission. In a given location, the missions themselves repeat the same maps except in different orders and arrangements. Also, a lot of the interesting skills and mechanics are at levels that are many hours away.The Source engine graphics look pretty and the physics lead to amusing sights. Not so amusing are the times when item drops glitch under the ground or when the frame rate takes a dive when a group of barrels are smashed simultaneously.Still, the thrill of defeating monsters is great, especially with a party. And you get to have a sword-&-shield woman kick a kobold in the face with thunderous impact.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												One of the most creative MMOs that I have ever played; the Source Engine physics and interactive, environments, make it one of the best free-to-play games available. Not only can you destroy objects and use them as weapons, but when you take down enemies, you can also pick up their corpse and beat other enemies to death with them. Another feature that makes this game interesting is the interaction with the enemies. In most games when you cut enemies with a giant Cloud-Strife-style broadsword, they keep attacking as if nothing happened. In Vindictus, if you hit them with a giant hammer, they are guaranteed to stagger a bit. Simply put, the physics in this game make it great.On the downside, the game can be very time consuming, especially when you’re trying to craft equipment; it takes several runs of different levels to get all the items you’ll need (and I heard it only gets harder as you reach higher levels).

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												To anyone wanting to venture in, the game's difficulty ramps up incredibly at around level 35. And then once you hit level 60 the only way to survive in the game is to learn how to fight against massive raid bosses and do very difficult "hero" mode battles for gold and drops to sell or use. This is not a game for the casual player. If you don't want to take the time to learn how to fight enemies and deal with all the losses that come before the one success that leads to successive successes then don't bother with this game.The game is free to play but there is a little item shop as well. PvP is all pay to win and it's not even a crucial part of the game. But to PvE efficiently you will at either have to be very lucky with RNG enhancing and enchanting or be prepared to unload your wallet for NX points to get at least +10 on your weapons and enhance items to sell.Overall, it's the one MMORPG that I will actually recommend to people because of the nature of the gameplay. It's action based and not click and wait. You have to be smart and learn when to attack enemy mobs and when to run and reposition and think ahead to what skill you need to use to avoid being hit. The problem increases against the higher level bosses and solving those mental puzzles is what makes the game very fun when you can feel proud of your achievement in predicting and reacting correctly.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2013
												Having played Vindictus before it was even released on steam, I can say that this is a very good, and well made MMO. I highly recommend trying it. The main complaint is the repetitiveness of it, and I can't argue with that. It has a lot of repetition. Nexon attempts to change it up, by changing certain things of certain features during certain parts of the game, and all in all the game can be VERY enjoyable.  The main feature of this game, that brings most of my interest into it, is that it is not the monotonous "Click 1 to cast spell, and wait for character to do it, then click second spell" type game, that most MMOs are now a days. This was also my main praise for Maplestory as well. That it didn't use the boring MMO-type way of fighting. Some call it "Real-Time" fighting. It is probably the most appropriate word for it. Another feature I really enjoy about this game, is that you can't really screw up your stats. Due to the skill "meditation", even if you put skill points into the wrong skill, you just have to wait about a week or so, and you simply GAIN skill points. That's right folks, in this game you can simply GAIN skill points just by having a character made. You don't even need to be online. So skilling your character is a LOT less stressful! But yes, Vindictus is a very enjoyable game, and I do recommend everyone at least try it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2012
												I've been playing this game for more than 2 years now. Over those years i've learned two things in specific that can make this game dificult or un-attractive for new players.1.The first two boats are pretty boring, the third boat onward it finally picks up.2. You need to find friends. Either from steam or a guild you find in game, make sure you get people to play with.The game itself, I love it. The graphics are nice, the music is amazing. The voice acting could use a little bit of work but meh. The other reason i've loved it is the amount of work required so to say. Its not just a gear2win MMO and "know your rotation". You have to be on your toes the whole time. Being able to actually dodge, and not just sitting in one spot, tanking hits and pressing 1-6, really freshens up the expirience.If you've been looking for something good and new (new style that is) come and play, and look me up!Update/Edit: with all the season two updates, this game has in general taken a turn for the better. the new boat system is more forgiving, bosses are getting harder and cooler, gear is badass, Hurk is fun as bawlls. And while I still take a hiatus from the game every so often, something always brings me back no matter how long I stop playing. I dont know if its the game or my guild or the new characters, I feel that coming back everytime speaks volumes for this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2012
												One of the best action MMORPG I've ever played. The combat mechanics are simple to grasp and yet difficult difficult to master. It truly takes skills to be one of the top players. While dungeon crawling gets tedious due to the large amount of weak mobs, it's the boss where all the fun is at. Every boss is unique in some way, and while the most skilled can solo, it is highly recommended to fight in a party. You think the regular bosses are too easy still? There are raid bosses where they are extremely unique and dangerous requiring parties of 8 (some even 24)!Since I am a fickle player when it comes to real money purchases, I am glad to say like League of Legends (yes, I sometimes play that...), real world money purchases do not extend any further than character "skins", inner armour, more inventory space, etc etc. Overall, Vindictus is one of the best, most rewarding, adrenaline pumping games I've ever played.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Just to be clear this isnt an open world game but that doesnt hurt the fact that it is a pretty worthwhile and fun experience. You go through quests like dungeons by going to the town and accepting the quests. Then you go to the docks and find the quest and dock the boat to go to the area. Quests/Gameplay:  As said above you dont find the places like in other games like this, you go to the dungeon specifically with or without people as you can choose as well as the difficulty. Normally though you will have to go back and do these same ones for side quests or just leveling up but eventually as the actual story progresses you will unlock new areas to go to and fight in as well as unlocking the higher difficulty stuff you can go back to after. Later on you unlock the area for raids and such but it is recommended in getting a lot of people with you as later on it is hard to find people to do those raids in.Characters:   As of making this review there are 8 characters (Lynn, Kai, Evie, Karok, Lann, Hurk, Vella, and Fiona). They are all more or less unique and fun to choose from. You have many skills to choose from and can somewhat change the appearence of them. I cant really describe each character as I havent played all of them but some of the characters have 2 weapons to choose from and others do not. You may easily find your play style in one of the characters. Overall I find each to be very helpful in a team.Story:  There is a very good story that is being told as you play. There are currently two seasons of the story. It is very rich in many things and helps you learn how to do things like enhance your items or learn how to do some of the side things like fish. Doing some of these side quests will earn you titles that show off what you did and could do later to enhance your stats or just show off a little. Overall the story is very rich and worthwhile.Free2play:  There are things you may pay for with real money but most of them are just outfits to make the women more naked or the men look weird or pretty nice looking. Its more or less for pets (that help a little) or just to show off. You can go through the game without paying real life money and they have a marketplace for crafting materials and the like to help you craft or just buy whatever with your virtual currency.Overall I recommend this game to anyone who just really wants a simple ORPG to play with their friends or play as a single player game and is tired of the norm of MMOs and wants something different.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Vindictus is a fun, entertaining hack & slash with memorable bosses and great gameplay. Unfortunately the game falls a bit short in its story, leveling, and high level community.Without spoiling anything, the story is extremely cheesy with unlikable characters who you just grow to hate. There aren't any redeeming qualities about the characters even when the developers try to force it upon you.The leveling gets very grindy really quick, unless you are willing to invest a few dollars into VIP services or you manage to happen upon one from a level up gift / special event.The high level community are pretty toxic, to the point that they won't even consider you if you don't have specific stats for your chosen character. If you didn't place your stats rights you are out of luck unless you are willing to invest some money into AP resets.Other than those fallbacks, the gameplay is still entertaining, addicting and worth the playtime.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												If I were to say anything about Vindictus is that it has the most intense combat of any free-to-play MMORPG out there. Take note: This game is not an open world experience, and can be summed up as an Instance run extravaganza. Every mission is just another instance. But don't let that discourage you. It is definitely a fun game. And while the only things that cost money are the cosmetic and inventory expansions, its a fair trade. No pay to win here. I've never dwelled on the PVP portions of the game but it is truly an experience best done with friends. Guild Bonuses are fun to work towards and the best thing about this game, is that if you are not one to play constantly, no problem. Once you get your character past the tutorial stuff, you can leave him be for months while he accumulates points to put towards leveling individual skills. Also note that these skills do have level caps so there it is not possible for a lvl 10 character to max out. But it's a nice feature to have, especially if you don't like grinding for points. Bottom line, it's a great beat em up experience that I'd highly recommend if you love action RPG's.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												End game is a huge ♥♥♥♥ fest of grinding for hours on end trying farm material and seals to craft lvl 70-80 weapons and armor. Also, the huge catch-22 in most mmorpgs is present in this game also; You don't have good gear so you can't join raids and so you can't get better gear because you can't run raids. In addition, there are titles that you have to grind for to gain small additional stat bonuses and it takes a ♥♥♥♥-ton of time to obtain them. The biggest issue with the game is that Nexon doesn't do♥♥♥♥♥♥to improve all of these mechanics. Everyone complains that the drop-rates are way too low and that unlike Asian communites, people aren't willing to grind for hours on end everyday to obtain semi-usable gear. Furthermore, nexon completely overprices their microtransactions and the only way to boost your dps is to use these microtransactions unless you're extremely lucky or extremely rich in-game. However, despite everything I said about this game. I ♥♥♥♥ing love it. The gameplay is amazing and I don't regret the amount of time that I spent grinding for lvl70 weapons and armor. Although, Nexon leaves a bad taste in my mouth, if you want a fun mmorpg with awesome gameplay and are willing to go that extra mile for gear, this game is perfect.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2012
												Vinductus is a fun, action packed, mmo that you can play with your friends for hours. The world is a dark place filled with monsters and little hope. To start off you must choose from one of five characters: Kai - ranger, Karok - brutish offensive tank, fiona - the defensive tank, lann - using dual weapons for lethal combos and evie the mage.Over all this is an extremly fun game and since it's free to play i reccomend giving it a try. The game does get a little repetetive especially since you have to repeat some of the same quests over and over for different tasks though thats the only downside I see.There is a level system, 70 being the highest and you achieve AP through battlequests (dungeons) that you use to upgrade your skills.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												I'm redoing this review because of yeah, I'm pretty sure Nexon got up off their arses and did something.Everything about this game is near perfect. In order to make an income, you need to collect items and sell them to other players. That leaves you with your own thoughts on, "If I set this much based on the original value, will someone buy it in the amount of time it is up?" I have sold several things in few seconds of posting them, due to the rarity item and the cost based on the maximum and minimum. Now that leaves a problem, getting money to do so in the first place, as it DOES take a fee to sell. Farm, or if you can, get a friend to donate money to you. [Option two is limited to those who were led to this game by a friend, or who have a friend who already has a large sum of in-game currency.] And to those complaining about Nexon making you pay for things, they make you pay for cosmetics. They are not needed for the main story, nor are they needed for 90% of the sub-stories. Stop complaining about it, as it is a simple want for the items you are being asked to pay for. Fighting is great, perfect. It is easy at the start but as you get higher and higher into the battle sequences, you find it challenging and you have to work as a team. The community is great, nobody complains from what I've seen, and when it comes to teamwork everyone is top-notch. The graphics are great, but of course that does depend on the strength of your graphics card/computer. I have to set mine to low, but at medium they are what I would say "High" for a F2P game. If I were to call this game anything, it would be "Battle Simulation". Nexon made this game to focus on breaking the limitations of battle in most MMORPGs, and they did. There is no wait time for skills, well, of course for the ones that do really high damage. But combo's are based on you, added to your timing and precision to dodge and attack enemies while taking little damage as possible is also up to you. The trade could use a few touch ups, along with gold. But mainly, this game is near perfect, and I would reccomend this to anyone.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												It'd be a good game if it wasn't an mmo. That being said, it's free so you might as well try it out. Getting through the main storyline won't require any $$$ from you.A lot of the negative things about Vindictus stem from the fact that it's an MMO, because most of the MMO aspects of it aren't great. Such as gearing up, which is a nightmare. Grindfest AND a chance based system? It's a little much and most players won't even bother, leaving those who do feeling superior to the rest of the population. It's a lot more enjoyable when you're with friends who don't judge you based on how much $$$ you spent. That being said, you don't really need good gear to have fun. It's a skill based game, gear is simply there to subsidize a lack of skill. I've seen people solo 8-man lv 60 & 70 (end game) content naked. This fact is the main reason I'm recommending it. That and it's free so even if you don't like it, who cares? Uninstall it and no harm is done. As a side note: some bosses discourage players who stack gear. For an example, arguablly one of the hardest bosses about a year ago, Keaghan, has an attack cap of 13.8k. So all the 20k att the wallet-warriors get screwed. A lot of the newer bosses encourage teamwork over DPS, like Bark No.1. Also, an upcoming boss, the succubus queen, has attacks that ignore defense completely in addition to being unable to revive in any way (even goddess graces, the paid method).The storyline is probably the best I've seen out of a F2P mmo.. ever. They really give all their NPCs a personality and if they die (which some do) you actually feel something. It's too bad the voice acting is terrible, but the way you get quest dialogue 90% of the time is reminiscent of graphic novel games. The graphics are of course outstanding, I don't think screen-shots really do the game justice. You can see your characters breath. If you're in a cold environment you see mist form around their mouth between each breath. If you run out of stamina they get a tired animation. Everything is very fluid and seems natural up until the source engine's clipping issue. If that doesn't bother you than you'll be hard pressed going back to the AAA mmo's with comparatively terrible graphics.I see a lot of reviewers don't mention it, but the soundtrack is absolutely outstanding. It becomes especially apparent in raids. The music really enhances the whole game and I strongly encourage any prospective players to check some of it out on youtube.As for events, the majoritoy of them are quiet silly and some of them really give you some valuable items which you'd normally have to pay a lot of money for. An example of a silly one, is they had a valve cross-over event with TF2 and portal characters making appearances. Which introduced funny titles like "pwn'd by GLaDoS" and ..interesting hats like the headcrab. content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												Vindictus is a pretty decent game. Not the best fantasy, MMORPG game out there but its ok. Vindictus is just like any other MMORPG game where you reside mainly in the town, journeying to different "stages" to complete a mission. I did experience a good amount of lag, low FPS, and crashes but it might just be me. Money is very hard to come by in the beginning of the game and you can buy next to nothing, even from the general merchants! Combat is extremely limited at the  beginning where all you do is swing your swords( Or whatever weapon you chose). One unique aspect that I noticed and reveled in was the ability you had to pick up environmental items and use them as weapons or projectiles, for example you could break a pillar and pick up a rock to throw at the monster. Overall, I would recommend you to try this game to see if its for you.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												I'm redoing this review because of yeah, I'm pretty sure Nexon got up off their arses and did something.Everything about this game is near perfect. In order to make an income, you need to collect items and sell them to other players. That leaves you with your own thoughts on, "If I set this much based on the original value, will someone buy it in the amount of time it is up?" I have sold several things in few seconds of posting them, due to the rarity item and the cost based on the maximum and minimum. Now that leaves a problem, getting money to do so in the first place, as it DOES take a fee to sell. Farm, or if you can, get a friend to donate money to you. [Option two is limited to those who were led to this game by a friend, or who have a friend who already has a large sum of in-game currency.] And to those complaining about Nexon making you pay for things, they make you pay for cosmetics. They are not needed for the main story, nor are they needed for 90% of the sub-stories. Stop complaining about it, as it is a simple want for the items you are being asked to pay for. Fighting is great, perfect. It is easy at the start but as you get higher and higher into the battle sequences, you find it challenging and you have to work as a team. The community is great, nobody complains from what I've seen, and when it comes to teamwork everyone is top-notch. The graphics are great, but of course that does depend on the strength of your graphics card/computer. I have to set mine to low, but at medium they are what I would say "High" for a F2P game. If I were to call this game anything, it would be "Battle Simulation". Nexon made this game to focus on breaking the limitations of battle in most MMORPGs, and they did. There is no wait time for skills, well, of course for the ones that do really high damage. But combo's are based on you, added to your timing and precision to dodge and attack enemies while taking little damage as possible is also up to you. The trade could use a few touch ups, along with gold. But mainly, this game is near perfect, and I would reccomend this to anyone.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												It'd be a good game if it wasn't an mmo. That being said, it's free so you might as well try it out. Getting through the main storyline won't require any $$$ from you.A lot of the negative things about Vindictus stem from the fact that it's an MMO, because most of the MMO aspects of it aren't great. Such as gearing up, which is a nightmare. Grindfest AND a chance based system? It's a little much and most players won't even bother, leaving those who do feeling superior to the rest of the population. It's a lot more enjoyable when you're with friends who don't judge you based on how much $$$ you spent. That being said, you don't really need good gear to have fun. It's a skill based game, gear is simply there to subsidize a lack of skill. I've seen people solo 8-man lv 60 & 70 (end game) content naked. This fact is the main reason I'm recommending it. That and it's free so even if you don't like it, who cares? Uninstall it and no harm is done. As a side note: some bosses discourage players who stack gear. For an example, arguablly one of the hardest bosses about a year ago, Keaghan, has an attack cap of 13.8k. So all the 20k att the wallet-warriors get screwed. A lot of the newer bosses encourage teamwork over DPS, like Bark No.1. Also, an upcoming boss, the succubus queen, has attacks that ignore defense completely in addition to being unable to revive in any way (even goddess graces, the paid method).The storyline is probably the best I've seen out of a F2P mmo.. ever. They really give all their NPCs a personality and if they die (which some do) you actually feel something. It's too bad the voice acting is terrible, but the way you get quest dialogue 90% of the time is reminiscent of graphic novel games. The graphics are of course outstanding, I don't think screen-shots really do the game justice. You can see your characters breath. If you're in a cold environment you see mist form around their mouth between each breath. If you run out of stamina they get a tired animation. Everything is very fluid and seems natural up until the source engine's clipping issue. If that doesn't bother you than you'll be hard pressed going back to the AAA mmo's with comparatively terrible graphics.I see a lot of reviewers don't mention it, but the soundtrack is absolutely outstanding. It becomes especially apparent in raids. The music really enhances the whole game and I strongly encourage any prospective players to check some of it out on youtube.As for events, the majoritoy of them are quiet silly and some of them really give you some valuable items which you'd normally have to pay a lot of money for. An example of a silly one, is they had a valve cross-over event with TF2 and portal characters making appearances. Which introduced funny titles like "pwn'd by GLaDoS" and ..interesting hats like the headcrab. A recent even gave out +10 coupons for free, simply for being logged on.All in all, if you can get past the mmo nasty-ness and nexons continuous attempts to get money out of you, it really is a great game.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2012
												My favorite mmorpg.  Most realistic feeling combat. My favorite part of this game is the diversity -Classes are inbalanced so pvp is not popular here, but each class has it's own weaknesses and strengths and no one class is the best against every kind of monster/boss. On top of each class being 100% unique, each one has it's own kind of sub classes, which are also very unique to each other.On top of that, while it's possible, it's very hard to be the best all-around character in terms of speed, strength, and survivability.  Each contribute to dps in their own way and the most effecient is purely dependent on your play style.While most end-game players seem very similar, variety in the types of players during mid-game is huge.You can be the fastest,the strongest, the tankiest,the most strategic,the most supportive,and probably much more.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												If I were to say anything about Vindictus is that it has the most intense combat of any free-to-play MMORPG out there. Take note: This game is not an open world experience, and can be summed up as an Instance run extravaganza. Every mission is just another instance. But don't let that discourage you. It is definitely a fun game. And while the only things that cost money are the cosmetic and inventory expansions, its a fair trade. No pay to win here. I've never dwelled on the PVP portions of the game but it is truly an experience best done with friends. Guild Bonuses are fun to work towards and the best thing about this game, is that if you are not one to play constantly, no problem. Once you get your character past the tutorial stuff, you can leave him be for months while he accumulates points to put towards leveling individual skills. Also note that these skills do have level caps so there it is not possible for a lvl 10 character to max out. But it's a nice feature to have, especially if you don't like grinding for points. Bottom line, it's a great beat em up experience that I'd highly recommend if you love action RPG's.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												End game is a huge ♥♥♥♥ fest of grinding for hours on end trying farm material and seals to craft lvl 70-80 weapons and armor. Also, the huge catch-22 in most mmorpgs is present in this game also; You don't have good gear so you can't join raids and so you can't get better gear because you can't run raids. In addition, there are titles that you have to grind for to gain small additional stat bonuses and it takes a ♥♥♥♥-ton of time to obtain them. The biggest issue with the game is that Nexon doesn't do♥♥♥♥♥♥to improve all of these mechanics. Everyone complains that the drop-rates are way too low and that unlike Asian communites, people aren't willing to grind for hours on end everyday to obtain semi-usable gear. Furthermore, nexon completely overprices their microtransactions and the only way to boost your dps is to use these microtransactions unless you're extremely lucky or extremely rich in-game. However, despite everything I said about this game. I ♥♥♥♥ing love it. The gameplay is amazing and I don't regret the amount of time that I spent grinding for lvl70 weapons and armor. Although, Nexon leaves a bad taste in my mouth, if you want a fun mmorpg with awesome gameplay and are willing to go that extra mile for gear, this game is perfect.
